revision.text:
The '''film industry in [[Louisiana]]''' has grown dramatically in recent years<ref name="Scott">Mike Scott, [http://www.nola.com/movies/index.ssf/2014/03/louisiana_outpaces_los_angeles.html "Louisiana outpaces Los Angeles, New York and all others in 2013 film production, study shows"], ''[[Times-Picayune]]'', March 10, 2014.</ref><ref name="about">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmla.com/uploads/2013%20Feature%20Production%20Report%20w%20Release%20030614_1394125127.pdf|title=2013 Feature Production Report}}</ref> largely due to the state's 2002 [[tax incentive]]s aimed at attracting film and television companies.<ref name="about"/> The success of [[Louisiana]]'s [[film industry]] caused the state to be nicknamed "Hollywood South" or "Hollywood on the Bayou".<ref name="fbtfilm">{{cite web|url=http://www.fbtfilm.com/hollywood-south.aspx|title=Louisiana Film Tax Incentives Help Create "The Second Hollywood South" |publisher=FBT Film & Entertainment|accessdate=2012-02-28}}</ref><ref>http://wayinto.com/atlanta/hollywood-of-the-south/</ref> In 2013, by some measures, film and television production in Louisiana exceeded that of California for the first time.<ref name="Scott"/>
==History== ===Early era=== Film-making in Louisiana began in 1898 with the [[Biograph Company|American Mutoscope and Biograph Company]].<ref name="timeline">{{cite web|url=http://www.louisianafilmmuseum.org/Louisiana_Filmography.html|title=Louisiana Filmography: 1898-1980|author=Louisiana Film Museum|accessdate=2012-02-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323140558/http://www.louisianafilmmuseum.org/Louisiana_Filmography.html|archive-date=2012-03-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> It has been the site of several notable productions over the years, the first of which was ''[[Tarzan of the Apes (film)|Tarzan of the Apes]]'', completed in 1918. Other earlier film productions include ''[[Jezebel]]'', ''[[A Streetcar Named Desire (1951 film)|A Streetcar Named Desire]]'', ''[[Easy Rider]]'', ''[[Live and Let Die (film)|Live and Let Die]]'', and ''[[The Big Easy (film)|The Big Easy]]''.<ref name="fbtfilm"/>
Louisiana has hosted a long list of major film and television stars over the years whose reputations and talents have likely played a role in the rise of state's film industry. Some of these actors and actresses include Bette Davis, Henry Fonda, Paul Newman, Marlon Brando, Denzel Washington, John Wayne, Clint Eastwood, Julia Roberts, Dennis Hopper, Cicely Tyson, Elvis Presley, Dennis Quaid, John Goodman, Jessica Lange, Richard Pryor, Jackie Gleason, James Spader, Dolly Parton, Susan Sarandon, Tommy Lee Jones, Kevin Costner, Tom Cruise, Alec Baldwin, Yul Brenner, David Niven, Jimmy Stewart, James Mason, Brad Pitt, Charles Bronson, and Daryl Hannah.<ref name="background">{{cite web|url=http://www.louisianafilmmuseum.org/|title=Background on the Museum|publisher=Louisiana Film Museum|accessdate=2012-02-28}}</ref>
===Modern era=== In 2002, Louisiana passed unique{{citation-needed|date=June 2015}} tax incentives aimed at recruiting film and television productions to the state. By 2011, the state's skilled crew base had grown by over 400 percent, and since 2006 over 300 [[film]]s have been shot in Louisiana. The industry truly entered the national spotlight though when ''[[The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (film)|The Curious Case of Benjamin Button]]'' earned thirteen [[Academy Award|Oscar]] nominations, the most in 2009.<ref name="about"/>
In 2010, boosted by its film industry, Louisiana made its first appearance in [[Site Selection (magazine)|Site Selection Magazine]]’s Top Business Climate rankings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fbtfilm.com/site-selection-2010.aspx|title=Film industry helps Louisiana earn Top 10 state ranking|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2011 Louisiana hosted more than 150 productions and about $1.3 billion of their combined $1.9 billion in budgets was spent in the state.<ref name="2011record">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmneworleans.org/2012/uncategorized/louisiana-film-industry-passes-billion-dollar-mark-in-record-setting-2011/|title=Louisiana Film Industry Passes Billion-Dollar Mark In Record-Setting 2011|author=Mike Scott|accessdate=2012-02-28}}</ref>
==Tax incentives== On July 1, 2002, the [[Louisiana Legislature]] enacted the Louisiana Motion Picture Tax Incentive Act.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://revenue.louisiana.gov/publications/lsleb(2002).pdf | title=2002 Legislative Sessions Department of Revenue Enrolled Bills | date=2002 | accessdate=August 20, 2016}}</ref> This [[tax credit]] has two primary components. First, the Investor Tax Credit provides a 30% tax credit on qualified motion picture expenditures with no project or program cap. Second, the Labor Tax Credit provides a 5% credit for [[payroll]] expenditures on Louisiana residents.<ref name="louisianaeconomicdevelopment.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.louisianaeconomicdevelopment.com/opportunities/incentives--programs/motion-picture-tax-credit.aspx|title=Motion Picture Industry Development Tax Credit|publisher=LED|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100123175417/http://www.louisianaeconomicdevelopment.com/opportunities/incentives--programs/motion-picture-tax-credit.aspx|archivedate=January 23, 2010|deadurl=y}}</ref> This program not only encourages residents to film in Louisiana but also employ Louisiana residents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fbtfilm.com/film_incentives.aspx|title=Louisiana Film Incentive & Tax Credit Program Information|publisher=}}</ref> To qualify for this program, [[filmmaker]]s must spend at least $300,000 in Louisiana.<ref name="louisianaeconomicdevelopment.com"/>
==Climate and scenery== Louisiana's warm weather and diverse locations have appealed to film producers across the country considering that the [[subtropical climate]] makes filming possible year-round without interruptions.<ref name="shreveport">{{cite web|url=http://www.shreveportla.gov/pictures/pics.htm|title=Shreveport Film and Media Industry|author=Cedric B. Glover|accessdate=2012-02-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224103832/http://www.shreveportla.gov/pictures/pics.htm|archive-date=2012-02-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="locations">{{cite web|url=http://www.louisianaentertainment.gov/film/content.cfm?id=87|title=Locations|author=Louisiana FILM|accessdate=2012-02-28}}</ref> The spring and fall months are considered ideal filming time, with October being the driest month.<ref name="weather">{{cite web|url=http://www.louisianaentertainment.gov/film/content.cfm?id=111|title=Weather Patterns|author=Louisiana FILM|accessdate=2012-02-28}}</ref> In terms of scenery, Louisiana offers [[swamp]]s and [[cypress]] trees, public and private college campuses, [[Antebellum architecture|antebellum plantations]], and urban environments. These diverse locations are often credited for Louisiana's ability to stand in as multiple settings such as [[Texas]], [[Colorado]], [[Utah]], [[Washington, DC]], and [[London]]. As [[Patrick Lussier]], director of [[Drive Angry]] 3D, commented in [[USA Today]], "The film industry wants to find places it can reinvent and make look like anything it needs. There's a lot of opportunity [to] do that in Louisiana."<ref name="Lussier">{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2010-08-03-louisianafilm03_CV_N.htm|title=Versatile Louisiana becomes 'L.A. South' for movie shoots|author=Claudia Puig|date=2010-08-03|accessdate=2012-02-28|work=USA Today}}</ref>
==Current film and television projects== # ''[[Bad Girls Club]]'' Season 7, (television series) # ''[[Killing Them Softly]]'' (feature film) # ''[[Ender's Game (film)|Ender's Game]]'' (feature film) # ''The Fishies'' (television series) # ''Ghostbreakers'' (television series) # ''[[The Host (2013 film)|The Host]]'' (feature film) # [[Super (2010 American film)|Super]] (feature film) # ''Hound Dogs'' (television series) # ''[[Looper (film)|Looper]]'' (feature film) # ''Oblivion'' (feature film) # ''[[On the Road (film)|On the Road]]'' (feature film) # ''Rook'' (feature film) # ''Seven Below Zero'' (feature film) # ''[[Tarantula (film)|Tarantula]]'' (feature film) # ''[[Treme (TV series)|Treme]] Season 2'' (television series) # ''[[True Blood]]'' (television series) # ''[[Universal Soldier: A New Dimension]]'' (feature film)<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.louisianaentertainment.gov/film/projects.cfm?status=2 | title=Projects | publisher=LED | accessdate=August 20, 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721044656/http://www.louisianaentertainment.gov/film/projects.cfm?status=2 | archivedate=July 21, 2011 | deadurl=y}}</ref>
==Notes== <references/> {{CinemaoftheUS}}
[[Category:Cinema of the United States]] [[Category:Economy of Louisiana]] [[Category:Film industry]]

'''Fragmentarium''' (Digital Research Laboratory for Medieval Manuscript Fragments) is an online database to collect and collate fragments of [[Middle Ages|medieval]] [[manuscripts]] making them available to researchers, collectors and historians worldwide. It is an international collaboration of major libraries and collections including the [[British Library]], [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]], [[Martin Schøyen Collection]], [[Bavarian State Library]], [[Harvard]], [[Yale]] and the [[Vatican Library|Vatican]]. It is based in [[Switzerland]] and the project's current director is Professor Christoph Flüeler from the [[University of Fribourg]] and the Virtual Manuscript Library, Switzerland.<ref name="nyt2017">{{cite web|last1=Kahn|first1=Eve M.|title=Yale Buys Collection of Scattered Medieval Pages|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/04/arts/design/yale-buys-collection-of-scattered-medieval-pages.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=18 September 2017}}</ref> [[File:Annotations de Florus de Lyon, fol. 16v.jpg|thumb|[[Florus de Lyon]] fragment, [[Bibliothèque Publique et Universitaire (Geneva)|Bibliothèque de Genève]], Ms. lat. 16]]
==History== The Fragmentarium project was first proposed in October 2013 and the first planning meeting took place in [[Cologny]] in 2014. It was supported initially by representatives of 12 institutions, its goal being to study the field of manuscript fragment research and look at worldwide cataloguing standards. Fragmentarium was officially launched on 1 September 2017, by the Medieval Institute of the University of Fribourg at [[Abbey Library of St. Gall]] in [[St. Gallen]], Switzerland.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fragmentarium Launched|url=http://www.fragmentarium.unifr.ch/about/news|website=Fragmentarium|accessdate=18 September 2017}}</ref> Historians and librarians are now able to upload images to the Fragmentarium where they will be made available for research and encouraged to publish images under a [[Creative Commons]] [[public domain license]].<ref name=bl2017>{{cite web|last1=Dunning|first1=Andrew|title=Fragmentarium and the burnt Anglo-Saxon fragments|url=http://blogs.bl.uk/digitisedmanuscripts/2017/09/fragmentarium-and-the-burnt-anglo-saxon-fragments.html|website=British Library: Medieval Manuscripts|accessdate=18 September 2017}}</ref> The library currently operates as a closed system and will open up public resources gradually from 2018.
==Method== [[File:Three palimpsest fragments Or. 6581.jpg|thumb|Multispectral image of [[palimpsest]] fragments Or. 6581 with infrared (middle) and ultraviolet (right)]] [[File:Composite images Or. 6581 palimpsest fragments.jpg|thumb|Enhanced multispectral imaging of palimpsest fragments composite images]] Fragmentarium follows an established Swiss [[codex]] digitisation system known as e-codices and aims to promote cooperative research and discussion between researchers and scholars from multiple institutions.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kahn|first1=Eve M.|title=Antiquarian Book Fair Offers Victorian Children’s Peep Shows|url=http://www.e-codices.unifr.ch/en/about/history|website=The New York Times|accessdate=18 September 2017}}</ref> As more fragments are uploaded it will be possible to reunite fragments which have become separated and compare analyses of similar manuscript pieces.<ref>{{cite web|title=Online-Plattform erleichtert die Erforschung alter Handschriften|url=http://www.freiburger-nachrichten.ch/nachrichten/online-plattform-erleichtert-die-erforschung-alter-handschriften|website=Freiburger Nachrichten|accessdate=18 September 2017}}</ref> Some fragments have been analysed using the [[Cornell Laboratory for Accelerator-based Sciences and Education#CHESS|Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source (CHESS)]] to identify pigments, creating a unique "fingerprint" to enable it to be matched to corresponding fragments elsewhere in the world and potentially track their journey with “the potential to learn more about trade routes, historic mining sites, and the regional use of pigments and ingredients”.<ref name="cc2017">{{cite web|last1=Aloi|first1=Daniel|title=Out of the blue: Medieval fragments yield surprises|url=http://news.cornell.edu/stories/2017/07/out-blue-medieval-fragments-yield-surprises|website=Cornell Chronicle|accessdate=22 September 2017}}</ref> Other fragments have been identified as "recycled" into covers or bindings for later documents, a practice which was prevalent in the 15th to 17th century.<ref name="srf2017">{{cite web|title=Recycling von Pergament Handschriften - Puzzle in der Stiftsbibliothek|url=https://www.srf.ch/news/regional/ostschweiz/handschriften-puzzle-in-der-stiftsbibliothek|website=Schweizer Radio und Fernsehen (SRF)|accessdate=22 September 2017}}</ref> The system is also useful in documenting and digitally preserving partial manuscripts which have been damaged by neglect or fire as in the [[Cotton library#Ashburnham House fire|Cotton library fire]] of 1731,<ref name=bl2017/> or by deliberate destruction as occurred in the reformation in [[Scandinavia]].<ref name=lz2017/> In more recent times, in the 1950s and 1960s medieval manuscripts were frequently deliberately divided in order to attract a higher return on resale values and have subsequently become lost to researchers: Fragmentarium hopes to reunite them. Flüeler has estimated that around 90% of extant fragments are currently "lost" in archives.<ref name=lz2017>{{cite web|last1=Knellwolf|first1=Bruno|title=Schnipseljagd mit Big Data|url=http://www.luzernerzeitung.ch/nachrichten/panorama/schnipseljagd-mit-big-data;art9645,1094273|website=Luzerner Zeitung|accessdate=22 September 2017}}</ref>
Access to the library is free of charge.<ref name="frag2017">{{cite web|title=Digital Library|url=http://www.fragmentarium.unifr.ch/about/digital-library|website=Fragmentarium|accessdate=25 September 2017}}</ref>
==Participants and donors== As of 2017 the following institutions are partner participants in Fragmentarium: *[[Abbey library of Saint Gall]] *[[Bayerische Staatsbibliothek]], [[Munich]] *[[Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana]] *[[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] *[[Bodleian Library]] in association with [[St Edmund Hall]], [[Oxford University]] *[[The British Library]] *Center for History and Palaeography of the [[National Bank of Greece Cultural Foundation]] *[[Harvard University]] *[[Herzog August Library]] *[[Martin Schøyen Collection]], [[Oslo]] *[[Medieval Academy of America]] *[[Österreichische Nationalbibliothek]] *[[Stanford University Libraries]] *[[Universitätsbibliothek Leipzig]] *[[Università degli Studi di Cassino]] *[[Universitätsbibliothek Leipzig]] *[[University of Pennsylvania Libraries]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Fragmentarium - An international scholarly network that enables libraries, collectors, researchers and students to upload medieval manuscript fragments and to describe, transcribe and assemble them online.|url=http://www.e-codices.unifr.ch/newsletter/archive/issue-18.html#fragmentarium|website=E-Codices|accessdate=18 September 2017}}</ref>
Fragmentarium is financially supported by the [[Stavros Niarchos Foundation]], the [[Swiss National Science Foundation]] and the Zeno-Karl-Schindler Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Donors|url=http://www.fragmentarium.unifr.ch|website=Fragmentarium|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref>
<gallery> File:St. Gallen, Stiftsbibliothek St. Gallen, Cod. Sang. 1397 V – Psalterium Gallicanum.jpg|[[Latin Psalters#Versio Gallicana|Psalterium Gallicanum]] medieval manuscript fragment used as book binding File:Fragment lat. 351, Charter from Leipzig, Universitätsbibliothek.jpg|Single leaf parchment fragment dated 1467-1500 CE from Leipzig with annotation by Johannes Falkenhayn File:Necrologium monasterii Altzelle – Reconstruction Parchment.jpg|Necrologium monasterii Altzelle reconstructed parchment dated 1186-1250 CE File:Paulinus Mediolanensis, Vita Ambrosii – Fragment.jpg|[[Paulinus Mediolanensis]], Vita Ambrosii fragment Le VI 12, Binding A File:Salvianus, Ad ecclesiam parchment fragment.jpg|[[Salvian|Salvianus]], [[Salvian#Ad ecclesiam|Ad ecclesiam]] parchment fragment, 2 leaves (trimmed) dated 901-925 CE, [[Fulda]] </gallery>
==See also== *[[Conservation and restoration of illuminated manuscripts]] *[[Digital Scriptorium]] *[[Palimpsest]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.fragmentarium.unifr.ch Fragmentarium website]
[[Category:Discipline-oriented digital libraries]] [[Category:Medieval literature]] [[Category:Online archives]] [[Category:British Library-related articles]] [[Category:Digital Research]] [[Category:Manuscripts]]

revision.comment: Added more information as to why this technology is attractive and an additional practical use-case.
revision.text:
[[File:Generative Design Process.png|thumbnail| Schema of Generative design as an iterative process]] [[File:Samba Collection.JPG|thumb|Samba, a furniture created by [[Guto Requena]] with generative design.]] '''Generative design''' is an [[Iteration|iterative]] [[design]] [[Process (engineering)|process]] that involves a [[Computer program|program]] that will [[Generator (mathematics)|generate]] a certain number of [[Output (computing)|outputs]] that meet certain [[Constraint (mathematics)|constraints]], and a [[designer]] that will fine tune the [[feasible region]] by changing [[Maxima and minima|minimal and maximal]] values of an [[Interval (mathematics)|interval]] in which a [[Variable (mathematics)|variable]] of the program meets the [[Set (mathematics)|set]] of constraints, in order to reduce or augment the number of outputs to [[Choice|choose]] from. The program doesn't need to be run on a [[machine]] like a [[digital computer]], it can be run by a human for example with [[pen and paper]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.evaburger.at/portfolio/generative-design-with-analogue-techniques/|title=generative design with analogue techniques – eva designs|website=www.evaburger.at|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> The designer doesn't need to be a [[human]], it can be a [[Test (assessment)|test]] program in a testing environment or an [[artificial intelligence]] (see for example [[Generative adversarial network|Generative adversarial networks]]). The designer [[Learning|learns]] to [[Refinement (computing)|refine]] the program (usually involving [[Algorithm|algorithms]]) with each iteration as his design [[Goal|goals]] become better [[Definition|defined]] over time.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cimdata.com/en/news/item/8402-generative-design-what-s-that|title=“Generative Design” – What’s That? - CIMdata|last=Meintjes|first=Keith|access-date=2018-06-15|language=en-gb}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.autodesk.com/solutions/generative-design|title=What is Generative Design {{!}} Tools & Software {{!}} Autodesk|access-date=2018-06-15|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/what-generative-design-anthony-hauck|title=What is Generative Design?|date=2018-04-09|access-date=2018-06-15|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://designbyming.com/relational-design-thinking/|title=Relational Design Thinking — Design by Ming|website=designbyming.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref>
The output could be [[Image|images]], [[Sound|sounds]], [[Architectural model|architectural models]], [[animation]], and much more. It is therefore a fast method of exploring design possibilities that is used in various design fields such as [[art]], [[architecture]], [[Communication Design|communication design]], and [[Product Design|product design]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.engineering.com/DesignSoftware/DesignSoftwareArticles/ArticleID/16973/Generative-Design-The-Road-to-Production.aspx|title=Generative Design: The Road to Production|last=ENGINEERING.com|website=www.engineering.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref>
The process combined with the [[Computing power|power]] of digital computers that can explore a very large number of possible [[Permutation|permutations]] of a solution enables designers to generate and test brand new options, beyond what a human alone could accomplish, to arrive at a most effective and optimized design. It [[Biomimetics|mimics nature]]’s [[evolutionary]] approach to design through [[genetic variation]] and [[Selection (biology)|selection]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.autodesk.com/customer-stories/airbus|title=Definition adapted from a product developed by Autodesk named Generative Design|website=Autodesk|accessdate=30 March 2017}}</ref>
Generative design is becoming more important, largely due to new programming environments or scripting capabilities that have made it relatively easy, even for designers with little programming experience, to implement their ideas. Additionally, this process can create solutions to substantially complex problems that would otherwise be resource-exhaustive with an alternative approach making it a more attractive option for problems with a large or unknown solution set.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/1003551283|title=Compositional model-based design: A generative approach to the conceptual design of physical systems|last=Prasanta|first=Rajamoney, Shankar A. Rosenbloom, Paul S.; Wagner, Chris Bose,|date=2014-09-04|publisher=University of Southern California|oclc=1003551283}}</ref> It is also facilitated with tools in commercially available [[Computer-aided design|CAD]] packages. Not only are implementation tools becoming more accessible but also tools leveraging generative design as a foundation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Fraser|last2=Grossman|first2=Tovi|last3=Fitzmaurice|first3=George|date=2017-10-20|title=Trigger-Action-Circuits: Leveraging Generative Design to Enable Novices to Design and Build Circuitry|url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3126594.3126637|publisher=ACM|pages=331–342|doi=10.1145/3126594.3126637|isbn=9781450349819}}</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Generative art]] * [[Computer art]] * [[Computer-automated design]] * [[Feedback]] * [[System dynamics]] * [[Genetic algorithm|Genetic algorithms]] * [[Random number generation]] * [[Procedural modeling]] * [[Topology optimization]]
== References == {{Reflist}} * Gary William Flake: ''The Computational Beauty of Nature: Computer Explorations of Fractals, Chaos, Complex Systems, and Adaptation''. MIT Press 1998, {{ISBN|978-0-262-56127-3}} * John Maeda: ''Design by Numbers'', MIT Press 2001, {{ISBN|978-0-262-63244-7}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.cad.2010.09.009 |title=A practical generative design method |journal=Computer-Aided Design |volume=43 |pages=88–100 |year=2011 |last1=Krish |first1=Sivam }} * Celestino Soddu: papers on Generative Design (1991-2011) at http://www.generativedesign.com/papers.html * Anthony Hauck: https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/what-generative-design-anthony-hauck/ * http://reneepuusepp.com/what-is-generative-design/ * US Patent on Generative Design - "Method and system of automating design" at http://www.google.ch/patents/US20070078634
{{Design}}
[[Category:Design]] [[Category:Computer graphics]]

revision.comment: /* Dance */clean up, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: world-wide → worldwide using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox Theatre |name = Giant Olive Theatre Company |image = The Hostess of the Inn.jpg |caption = The Hostess of the Inn |website = www.giantolive.com }}
'''Giant Olive Theatre Company''' was founded in the summer of 2008 by Artistic Director [[George Sallis]]. The company stages classical theatre, [[commedia dell'arte]], dance, contemporary plays, comedy, new writing and has become well known for its Charles Dickens Christmas adaptations along with its bold dance projects including the GOlive Dance and Performance Festival, curated by Donald Hutera (The Times).
[[Hugh Bonneville]] is a Patron of the Company. Associate artists include [[Ray Shell]] ([[Starlight Express]], [[The Lion King]]), Antonia Franceschi ([[Fame (musical)|FAME]], [[New York City Ballet]]), Mark Baldwin [[Rambert Dance Company]] and Zoe Martlew.
== Dance == [[File:GO Gala Photo.jpg|thumb|From left to right: Hugh Bonneville, George Sallis, Antonia Franceschi, Mark Baldwin, Richard Alston, Martin Lawrence, 22 January 2011]]
In 2013, Giant Olive produced the inaugural GOlive Dance and Performance festival, curated by veteran arts journalist Donald Hutera, whose writing has appeared in The Times, Time Out, Dance Europe and many other publications and websites worldwide. The festival patrons were Siobhan Davies and Rosemary Butcher. Spread across 21 consecutive days, and comprising over four dozen individuals or companies, the GOlive Festival featured work by Darren Ellis, Ella Mesma, Renaud Wiser, Anusha Subramanyam, Daniel Hay-Gordon/Eleanor Perry, 70/30 Split, Shane Shambhu, Nuno Silva, Moreno Solinas, Peta Lily, The Dangerologists, Stephanie Schober, Anna Williams, Stopgap's Sg2, Angela Woodhouse, Dog Kennel Hill Project, Avatâra Ayuso, Mickael Marso Rivière, Jennifer Jackson/Susie Crow, Annie Lok, Zoi Dimitriou and Fred Gehrig amongst many others. Between them the artist involved had worked with the likes of Complicite, Richard Alston, Siobhan Davies, Shobana Jeyasingh, Russell Maliphant, The Royal Ballet, Wayne McGregor|Random Dance, Rambert Dance Company, Henri Oguike, Arthur Pita and Fiona Shaw.
In 2011, George Sallis and Antonia Franceschi teamed up to produce a Gala performance, to mark the closure of the Lion & Unicorn Theatre for refurbishment. The evening included performances choreographed by [[Richard Alston (choreographer)|Richard Alston]], Mark Baldwin, Martin Lawrence, Jonathan Goddard with poetry directed by Patsy Rodenburg, and ‘Disco’ from Giant Olive’s POP8, again featuring Ballet Black.<ref>[http://www.londondance.com/news_details.asp?NewsID=8136 londondance.com] 28 January 2011</ref>
In June 2009 Giant Olive Theatre Company produced 'POP8' with Antonia Franceschi, a new dance theatre piece incorporating a short film by [[Tal Rosner]] and Franceschi set in [[Kentish Town]], and an additional film by Terry Braun also featuring Franceschi which was choreographed by [[Rambert Dance Company|Rambert's]] Mark Baldwin. Performers included Ballet Black dancers, resident at the Royal Opera House, Zoe Martlew on Cello and voiceovers from Franceschi and George Sallis directed by [[Patsy Rodenburg]]. The production was supported by Camden Council.<ref>http://www.giantolive.com/productions/giant-olive-previous-productions/pop8.html</ref> and received Critic's Choice in London's [[Time Out (company)|TimeOut]].
== The ZIP Project (Gun & Knife Crime) ==
Giant Olive received ''Time Out'' Critics Choice in 2010, for its Community Outreach project, 'ZIP:Gun & Knife Crime'. With the support of [[Big Lottery Fund|The Big Lottery Fund]], [[Camden Council (New South Wales)|Camden Council]] and [[Choice FM]], the company ran workshops in [[London Borough of Camden|Camden]] with people affected by gun and knife crime as victims or perpetrators. Working with the experiences and stories told, Giant Olive produced an original [[streetdance]] [[musical theatre|musical]]. The project was supported by Local MP, [[Frank Dobson|Rt Hon Frank Dobson]], [[Tulip Siddiq|Councillor Tulip Siddiq]], Councillor Abdul Hai and Chief Superintendent Neil Wilson.
== The Gaea Theatre Festival ==
The Gaea Theatre Festival celebrates international women playwrights, performers, directors and designers and was launched by Giant Olive in August 2011. The festival received 7 award nominations from the OffWestEnd.com Theatre Awards and Time Out Critic's Choice for Caroline Horton's 'I'll Show You Mine'.
== Little Olives ==
'''Little Olives''' is Giant Olive's children's theatre company.
==Productions== *''2015'' '''JUST DANCE''' UK Premiere. Produced by AFD/Giant Olive at the Theatre Royal Winchester, Choreography by Antonia Franceschi, featuring performers from the Royal Ballet, Rambert, Ballet Black and Random Dance <ref>[http://www.theatreroyalwinchester.co.uk/just-dance/ Theatre Royal Winchester listing] published 1 February 2015</ref> *''2013-2015'' '''GOlive Dance and Performance Festival''', Curated by Donald Hutera <ref>[http://www.timeout.com/london/dance/golive-a-chance-to-dance?intcid=leader] published 3 September 2013</ref> *''2011'' '''AN EXPERIMENT WITH AN AIR PUMP''', [[Shelagh Stephenson]], Directed by Liisa Smith,<ref>[http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/33982/experiment-with-an-air-pump Review in The Stage] published 24 October 2011</ref> *''2011'' '''I'LL SHOW YOU MINE''', Adapted and Performed by Caroline Horton, Produced by Giant Olive Theatre Company<ref>[http://www.giantolive.com/Review_TimeOut_i%27llshowyoumine.html CRITICS CHOICE Review by Whats On Stage] published 16 August 2011</ref> *''2011'' '''BEAUTY IS PRISON-TIME''', Written and Performed by Zoe Mavroudi,<ref>[http://www.whatsonstage.com/reviews/theatre/off-west+end/E8831312453751/Beauty+is+Prison-Time.html Review Whats On Stage] published 4 August 2011</ref> *''2011'' '''TOM JONES''', [[Henry Fielding]], Directed by Edward Kingham,<ref>[http://www.timeout.com/london/theatre/event/88158/tom-jones Review in Time Out] published 31 May 2011</ref> *''2011'' '''GO GALA''', George Sallis (GO Artistic Director), Antonia Franceschi (GO Artistic Advisor), Mark Baldwin (Artistic Director, Rambert), Richard Alston (Artistic Director, The Place), Martin Lawrence (Choreographer) <ref>http://www.londondance.com/news_details.asp?NewsID=8136 published 28 January 2011</ref> *''2010-11'' '''A CHRISTMAS CAROL''', [[Charles Dickens]]<ref>http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/30809/a-christmas-carol published 20 December 2010</ref> *''2010'' '''ZIP:Gun & Knife Crime''', Produced by George Sallis. *''2009-10'' '''OLIVER TWIST''', [[Charles Dickens]], Adapted by [[Piers Beckley]], Directed by [[Ray Shell]]<ref>[http://www.timeout.com/london/theatre/event/168708/oliver-twist Review in Time Out] published 21 December 2009''</ref> *''2009-10'' '''SUPERNATURAL''', Written by Aline Waites and Jago Turner, Directed by Mykal Rand<ref>[http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/26354/supernatural Review in The Stage] published 27 November 2009''</ref> *''2009'' '''KITTY AND DAMNATION''', Written by Joseph Crilly<ref>[http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/25279/kitty-damnation Review in The Stage] published 14 August 2009''</ref> *''2009'' '''POP8''' with Antonia Franceschi, Zoë Martlew and Ballet Black<ref>[http://www.timeout.com/london/dance/event/152624/pop8 Listing in TimeOut] Critics Choice 07/09</ref> *''2009'' '''GETTING OUT''', Sarah Henley, Directed by Francis Watson and Gillian Foley<ref>[http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/24180/getting-out Review in The Stage] /* List of works featuring Hap and Leonard */ Slight reorder
revision.text:
{{Infobox character | name = Leonard Pine and Hap Collins | series = | image = Hap and Leonard poster.png | caption = Promotional poster for the TV Series adapted from the books | first = ''[[Savage Season]]'' | last = | creator = [[Joe R. Lansdale]] | portrayer = [[James Purefoy]] (Hap)
[[Michael K. Williams]] (Leonard) | gender = Male | occupation = Private investigators | nationality = American }} '''Hap and Leonard''' are two fictional amateur investigators and adventurers portrayed by American author [[Joe R. Lansdale]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/books/1997-08-22/529456/|title=Joe Lansdale|last=Savlov|first=Marc|date=1997-08-22|work=[[The Austin Chronicle]]|access-date=2017-03-13|language=en-US}} They are the main characters in a series of ten novels, three [[novellas]], and three collections of stories and excerpts. They are two very different men and the best of friends, and now work together as private investigators for Hap's girlfriend Brett Sawyer. Together they always wind up in a lot of trouble with various criminal types in the fictional town of LaBorde, in [[East Texas]] and often find themselves attempting to solve various unpleasant and brutal crimes. Both men are well versed in the [[martial arts]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.thrillingdetective.com/hap.html|title=Hap Collins & Leonard Pine|last=Smith|first=Kevin Burton|date=2017|website=www.thrillingdetective.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822102400/http://www.thrillingdetective.com/hap.html|archive-date=2016-08-22|dead-url=no|access-date=2017-03-13}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/series/50105-hap-collins-and-leonard-pine|title=Hap and Leonard series by Joe R. Lansdale|date=2017|website=www.goodreads.com|archive-url=http://www.goodreads.com/series/50105-hap-collins-and-leonard-pine|archive-date=2017-03-12|dead-url=no|access-date=2017-03-13}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.mediamikes.com/2011/04/interview-with-joe-lansdale/|title=Interview with Joe R. Lansdale|last=Gencarelli|first=Mike|date=2011-04-11|website=www.mediamikes.com|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422092237/http://www.mediamikes.com/2011/04/interview-with-joe-lansdale/|archive-date=2016-04-22|dead-url=no|access-date=2017-03-13}}{{Cite web|url=http://subterraneanpress.com/magazine/spring_2009/interview_hap_and_leonard_by_joe_r._lansdale|title=Interview: Hap and Leonard by Joe R. Lansdale|last=Leonard|first=Joe R|date=Spring 2009|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160621052742/http://subterraneanpress.com/magazine/spring_2009/interview_hap_and_leonard_by_joe_r._lansdale|archive-date=2016-06-21|dead-url=y|access-date=}} The novels were adapted into a [[Hap and Leonard (TV series)|2016–18 TV series]], produced by [[SundanceTV]]. ==Hap Collins== Hap Collins is a white working class laborer who spent time in federal prison as a young man for refusing to be drafted into the military and serve in the [[Vietnam War]]. In his late forties, he is often haunted by the various unpleasant jobs he's held over the years such as working at an aluminum chair factory and working the East Texas rose fields. Hap tries his best to avoid violence and also tries his best to avoid the taking of another human life. Often lovesick, most of his relationships haven't worked out. He is currently with his on-again-off-again girlfriend Brett Sawyer. Some of his past has been taken from Mr. Lansdale's own past. The stories are told from Hap's narrative point of view. Not as quick to anger as Leonard, he often finds himself attempting to talk Leonard out of committing serious violence. ==Leonard Pine== Leonard Pine is a gay, black [[Vietnam vet]] with serious anger issues. He was raised by his uncle who shunned him after learning he was gay. However, when his uncle passes away, he leaves his house and all his assets to Leonard. Leonard has zero tolerance for racist or [[Homophobia|anti-gay]] slurs. Although Hap dislikes guns, Leonard has no problem carrying or using them. Quick to anger, at times he cannot understand Hap's aversion to violence or killing if necessary, even when provoked. His relationships are also short and tempestuous. Leonard is the much more aggressive of the two and repeatedly burned down a local [[crack house]] that used to be his new next door neighbor. After living with Hap and Brett for a while, he recently moved into his own place.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/johnny-shaw/the-descendants-of-holmes_b_5499245.html|title=The Descendants of Holmes and Watson: 11 Literary Partners-in-Crime|first=Johnny|date=|website=|publisher=Huffington Post|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150827203634/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/johnny-shaw/the-descendants-of-holmes_b_5499245.html|archive-date=2015-08-27|dead-url=no|last1=Shaw|accessdate=29 June 2014}} Much to Hap's dismay, Leonard has a habit of wearing ugly hats. ==Television adaptation== {{Main|Hap and Leonard (TV series)}} [[Cold in July (novel)|Film]] duo [[Nick Damici]] and [[Jim Mickle]] have developed a Hap and Leonard crime and suspense TV series for [[SundanceTV]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/cold-july-duo-nick-damici-jim-mickle-developing-stake-land-hap-leonard-tv-series-exclusive/|title=‘Cold in July’ Duo Nick Damici, Jim Mickle Developing Private Eye Series for Sundance Channel (Exclusive)|last=Zakarin|first=Jordan|date=2014-03-04|website=The Wrap|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231103940/http://www.thewrap.com/cold-july-duo-nick-damici-jim-mickle-developing-stake-land-hap-leonard-tv-series-exclusive/|archive-date=2016-12-31|dead-url=no|accessdate=2014-03-06}} On November 10, 2014, Sundance [[green-light|green-lit]] the series for six one-hour episodes, which filmed in 2015 and premiered on March 2, 2016.{{cite web |last=Kondolojy |first=Amanda |title=SundanceTV Expands Original Scripted Slate and Greenlights Drama 'Hap and Leonard' |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/11/10/sundancetv-expands-original-scripted-slate-and-greenlights-drama-hap-and-leonard/325738/|date=November 10, 2014 |accessdate=November 10, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=First Look: James Purefoy and Michael K. Williams|title=First Look: Hap and Leonard|url=https://www.yahoo.com/tv/first-look-michael-k-williams-and-james-purefoy-151759430.html?soc_src=social-sh&soc_trk=tw|website=Yahoo.com|accessdate=6 October 2015}}At the end of June [[SundanceTV]] renewed a second six episode season based on the second novel [[Mucho Mojo]].{{cite web|last1=Landale|first1=Joe R.|title=Renewal for season 2 on Sundance Channel|url=http://deadline.com/2016/06/hap-and-leonard-season-2-plans-sundancetv-1201760500/|website=Deadline.com|accessdate=18 August 2016}} On May 14, 2018, SundanceTV announced they had cancelled the series after three seasons.https://deadline.com/2018/05/hap-leonard-canceled-sundance-tv-michael-kenneth-williams-james-purefoy-1202391210/https://www.salon.com/amp/losing-hap-and-leonard-in-the-trump-age-this-show-was-an-inoculation-for-some-people?__twitter_impression=true{{cite web |last1=Black Girl |first1=Nerds |title="Hap and Leonard" Cancelled Because We Can't Have Nice Things |url=https://blackgirlnerds.com/hap-and-leonard-cancelled-because-we-cant-have-nice-things/?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter# |website=blackgirlnerds.com |accessdate=1 July 2018}} ==List of works featuring Hap and Leonard== # ''[[Savage Season]]'' http://www.thediaryofabookworm.com/2011/03/savage-season-hap-and-leonard-novel-by.html Review retrieved 10/20/12 (1990) # ''[[Mucho Mojo]]'' http://www.armchairinterviews.com/reviews/mucho-mojo Review Retrieved 10/19/12 (1994) # ''[[The Two-Bear Mambo]]'' http://trashotron.com/agony/reviews/lansdale-two_bear_mambo.htm Review Retrieved 10/20/12 (1995) # ''[[Bad Chili]]'' http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/102132.Bad_Chili Review Retrieved 10/21/12 (1997) # ''[[Rumble Tumble]]'' http://www.vachss.com/media/righteous/excerpt_tumble.html Review Retrieved 10/20/12 (1998) # ''[[Veil's Visit: a Taste of Hap and Leonard]]'' (1999) (short stories and excerpts written with [[Andrew Vachss]]) http://www.vachss.com/av_books/short_stories/veils_visit.html Review Retrieved 10/20/12 # ''[[Captains Outrageous]]'' http://www.mysteriousreviews.com/mystery-book-reviews/lansdale-captains-outrageous.html#.UIIsQ8XA-Vo Review Retrieved 10/21/12 (2001) # ''[[Vanilla Ride]]'' http://blogcritics.org/books/article/book-review-vanilla-ride-by-joe1/ Retrieved 10/20/12 (2009) # ''[[Devil Red]]'' http://www.bookreporter.com/reviews/devil-red-a-hap-leonard-novel Review Retrieved 10/21/12 (2011) # ''[[Hyenas: a Hap and Leonard Novella]]'' http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-59606-356-3 Review retrieved 10/21/12 (2011, novella) # ''[[Dead Aim (novella)|Dead Aim]]'' (novella){{cite web |url=http://subterraneanpress.com/store/product_detail/dead_aim |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130814053933/http://subterraneanpress.com/store/product_detail/dead_aim |archivedate=2013-08-14 |df= }} Release announcement (2013) # ''Honky Tonk Samurai'' (2016){{cite web|last1=Lansdale|first1=Joe R.|title=Honky Tonk Samurai Review|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/07/books/review/joe-r-lansdales-honky-tonk-samurai-and-more.html?_r=0|website=New York Times Book Review|accessdate=27 February 2016}} # ''Briar Patch Boogie'' (2016, novellette) # ''Hap and Leonard'' (2016, short story collection) # ''Hap and Leonard Ride Again'' (2016, short story collection) # ''Coco Butternut: A Hap and Leonard Novella'' (2017, novella) # ''Rusty Puppy'' (2017){{cite web|title=Rusty Puppy|url=https://www.hachettebookgroup.com/titles/joe-r-lansdale/rusty-puppy/9781478940821/|website=Hachette Book Group|accessdate=14 October 2016}} # ''Cold Cotton'' (2017, novella) # ''Hoodoo Harry'' (2017, novella){{cite web|last1=Lansdale|first1=Joe R.|title=Hoodoo Harry|url=http://www.mysteriousbookshop.com/products/joe-r-lansdale-hoodoo-harry|website=Release Information|publisher=The Mysterious Bookshop|accessdate=16 January 2017}} # ''Hap and Leonard: Blood and Lemonade'' (2017, [[Mosaic novel]]){{cite web|title=Hap and Leonard: Blood and Lemonade|url=https://tachyonpublications.com/product/hap-and-leonard-blood-and-lemonade/|website=Tachyon Publications|accessdate=14 October 2016}} # ''Jackrabbit Smile'' (2018) ==Graphic novels== A series of [[graphic novels]] were announced, to be published in 2015, but the dates have been tentatively pushed up to 2017.{{cite web|last1=Hellnotes Release Info.|title=Hap and Leonard Graphic Novels|url=http://hellnotes.com/hap-and-leonard-set-to-be-released-as-graphic-novels|website=Hellnotes|accessdate=13 July 2015}}Lansdale is also busy on other Hap and Leonard projects that will be announced at a later date. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.joerlansdale.com/ Joe R. Lansdale's official Website] *[http://hapandleonard.net/ Hap and Leonard's official website] *[http://subterraneanpress.com/ Subterranean Press Website] *[http://www.mulhollandbooks.com/author/joerlansdale/ Mulholland Books Website] *[http://www.randomhouse.com/book/search/search.php?title_subtitle_auth=joe+r.+lansdale&x=9&y=7 Vintage Crime/Black Lizard Website] *[https://tachyonpublications.com/book_author/joe-r-lansdale/ Tachyon Publications Website] *[http://www.horrordrive-in.com/serendipity/index.php?/categories/13-Homepage/ Horror Drive-In Homepage] {{Joe R. Lansdale}} [[Category:Fictional characters from Texas]] [[Category:Fictional gay males]] [[Category:Works by Joe R. Lansdale]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:American crime novels]] [[Category:Crime novel series]]

revision.text:
'''Jenő Bory''' ([[Székesfehérvár]], November 9, 1879 – Székesfehérvár, December 20, 1959) was a Hungarian architect and sculptor.
[[Image:Bory-var 2006 June.jpg|thumb|right|Bory Castle in Székesfehérvár]]
[[Image:Szekesfehervar 2005 11 009 kicsi.JPG|thumb|right|Column by Bory in Székesfehérvár]]
[[Image:Kaposvár Bory Szent István-kút.jpg|thumb|right|St Stephen's well in Kaposvar, part of Our Lady Church]]
Bory received his degree in building engineering in Budapest in 1903. He enrolled in the Academy of Fine Arts to study sculpture under [[Alajos Strobl]]. At this time he met his wife, Ilona Komocsin (1885-1974), who became a notable painter after finishing her studies in [[Szeged]]. During [[World War I]] as a soldier he was appointed as an official war artist in [[Sarajevo]] for which he received the Order of Franz Josef. He taught at the Academy of Fine Arts (1911–46) and at the Technical University (1921–44). He was rector of the Academy between 1943 and 1945.
He was largely responsible for the building of the so-called ''Bory castle'' in Székesfehérvár which is decorated by his and his wife's works. He built this fantastic, castle-like structure out of concrete with his own hands for 41 years. {{Commons category|Jenő Bory}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bory, Jenoe}} [[Category:1879 births]] [[Category:1959 deaths]] [[Category:People from Székesfehérvár]] [[Category:Hungarian architects]] [[Category:19th-century Hungarian people]] [[Category:20th-century Hungarian people]] [[Category:19th-century sculptors]] [[Category:20th-century Hungarian sculptors]] [[Category:19th-century Hungarian architects]] [[Category:20th-century Hungarian architects]] [[Category:Hungarian art]] [[Category:Hungarian University of Fine Arts]]
{{Hungary-sculptor-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:KS21454.jpg|thumb|FREE, 2012 exhibition of entries to the Koestler Awards curated by Sarah Lucas]] [[File:Catching Dreams-254.jpg|thumb|Catching Dreams-254]]The '''Koestler Trust''' or award scheme, is a [[Charitable organization|charity]] (Registered charity number 1105759 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charitycommission.gov.uk/find-charities/|title=Charity Commission}}</ref>) which helps ex-offenders, secure patients and detainees in the UK to express themselves creatively. The trust promotes the arts in prisons, secure hospitals, immigration centres and in the community, encouraging creativity and the acquisition of new skills as a means to [[Rehabilitation (penology)|rehabilitation]]. It was founded in 1962, by a [[bequest]] from the British-Hungarian author, [[Arthur Koestler]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web|title=History of the Koestler Trust|url=http://www.koestlertrust.org.uk/pages/history.html|work=Koestler Trust|accessdate=9 March 2013}}</ref>
==Koestler's prison experience==
Koestler had been detained in three jails in separate countries. In Spain, he was sentenced to death in 1936 for espionage under [[Francisco Franco]]'s regime.<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|title=Arthur Koestler 1905-1983|url=http://www.koestlertrust.org.uk/pages/arthurkoestler.html|work=Koestler Trust|accessdate=9 March 2013}}</ref> Here, he witnessed many executions, and was held in solitary confinement.<ref name="auto2">{{cite news|last=Menand|first=Louis|title=Road Warrior: Arthur Koestler and his century|url=http://www.newyorker.com/arts/critics/atlarge/2009/12/21/091221crat_atlarge_menand?currentPage=1|accessdate=9 March 2013|newspaper=The New Yorker|date=21 December 2009}}</ref> He was arrested in France a few years later and held in the [[Le Vernet Internment Camp]] for subversion.<ref name="auto1"/> Koestler was released and fled to England, where he was held at [[Pentonville (HM Prison)|Pentonville]] as a suspected illegal immigrant.<ref name="auto1"/>
==Creation of the Koestler Trust== His experiences in prison led him to write ''[[Darkness at Noon]]'' and newspaper articles campaigning for the abolition of capital punishment in the 1950s.<ref name="auto"/> He also attempted to change the experience of incarceration, stating that in prison, "the main problem is apathy, depression and gradual [[dehumanisation]]. The spark dies."<ref name="auto3">{{cite news|last=Chesshyre|first=Robert|title=The Fine Art of Starting Over|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2006/sep/17/art|accessdate=9 March 2013|newspaper=The Observer|date=16 September 2006}}</ref> Koestler spoke of being intellectually under-stimulated<ref name="auto3"/> and terrorized in prison,<ref name="auto2"/> and wanted to provide "an imaginative and exciting way to stimulate as far as possible and in as many cases as possible the mind and spirit of the prisoner."<ref name="auto"/>
In 1962, Koestler arranged the Arthur Koestler Award (now Koestler Trust) through the [[Home Office]] of the United Kingdom, to award monetary prizes for artistic achievement to prisoners, detainees, and psychiatric patients.<ref name="auto3"/>
==The Koestler Trust Today== Today the Koestler Awards cover over 61 artforms, across music, writing, crafts, design, performance and fine art. Each category is judged by panels of experts, including Grayson Perry, Jeremy Deller, V&A, National Theatre, Speech Debelle and Hot Chip (2014 UK Awards). An annual exhibition programme is curated separately and held at Southbank Centre. Recent curators of the UK exhibition include Grayson Perry, Sarah Lucas, Speech Debelle, Victims of Crime, Magistrates, women prisoners and ex-prisoners. The charity also holds locally-focused exhibitions - recent shows include Snail Porridge at Castlefield Gallery in Manchester (2014) curated by Bob and Roberta Smith, and Release at Glasgow's Tramway, curated by Kibble Secure Centre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koestlertrust.org.uk/pages/awards.html|title=Koestler Trust Awards|work=koestlertrust.org.uk}}</ref>
The Trust also runs mentoring programmes for people who wish to continue in the arts after release from prison or other secure settings.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.koestlertrust.org.uk/pages/exhibitions.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107135901/http://www.koestlertrust.org.uk/pages/exhibitions.html |archivedate=2014-11-07 |df= }}></ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Artforms|url=http://www.koestlertrust.org.uk/pages/awardsartform.html|work=Koestler Trust|accessdate=9 March 2013}}</ref> The prizes were initially paid by Koestler himself, but the award was reorganized into a charitable trust in 1969, as more sources of funding became necessary.<ref name="auto"/> Today, artwork by the prisoners and others is available for sale direct to the public through the trust's exhibitions. Artists receive 50% of proceeds, 25% goes to Victim Support and 25% to the Trust.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koestlertrust.org.uk/pages/buyart.html|title=Koestler Trust Art for sale|work=koestlertrust.org.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Art Sales|url=http://www.koestlertrust.org.uk/pages/buyart.html|work=Koestler Trust|accessdate=9 March 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Arthur Koestler}}
[[Category:Arthur Koestler]] [[Category:Mental health organisations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Penal system in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Health charities in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Arts foundations]] [[Category:Arts organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Prison charities based in the United Kingdom]]
#REDIRECT [[Volin]] {{R from book}}

{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Chinese words and phrases]]}} [[File:ArrestOfOrchid01R.jpeg|thumb|right|250px|A Lianhuanhua Image from ''"Arrest of the Orchid"'']] '''''Lianhuanhua''''' ([[Chinese character|Chinese]]: 连环画 ([[Simplified Chinese|Simplified]]) 連環畫 ([[Traditional Chinese|Traditional]]); [[Pinyin]]: ''Liánhuánhuà'' or 連環圖) is a [[Hand|palm-size]] picture book of sequential drawings found in [[China]] in the early 20th century.
There is a Chinese belief that ''lianhuanhua'' influenced Japanese [[manga]] in the 20th century.<ref name="Wendy">Wong, Wendy Siuyi. [2002] (2001) Hong Kong Comics: A History of Manhua. Princeton Architectural Press. New York. {{ISBN|1-56898-269-0}}</ref>
==Terminology== The name in Chinese essentially translates to "linked pictures" or "serial pictures". The books were called ''"lianhuanhua"'' or ''"lianhuan tuhua"''; later the "tu" was omitted and the term ''"lianhuanhua"'' became standard.<ref name="Lent">Lent, John A. [2001] (2001) Illustrating Asia: Comics, Humor Magazines, and Picture Books. University of Hawaii Press. {{ISBN|0-8248-2471-7}}</ref> The official term lianhuanhua was not used until 1927. Prior to this, lianhuanhua were separated into different name categories depending on the region.<ref name="Lent" />
{|class="wikitable" ! width=10% | Location ! width=25% | English Meaning ! width=25% | Chinese Name |- | [[Shanghai]] || Little Book || Xiao Shu (小書) |- | [[Shanghai]] || Picture Book || Tuhua Shu (圖畫書) |- | [[Guangzhou]] and [[Hong Kong]] || Doll Book || Gongzai Shu (公仔書) |- | [[Wuhan]] || Children's Book || Yaya Shu (伢伢書) |- | [[Northern and southern China|Northern China]] || Kid's Book || Xiaoren Shu (小人書) |- |}
==History== In the 1880s, Chinese magazines such as Dianshizhai Pictorial experimented with the potential of this art technique. In 1884, ten illustrations to accompany a [[Korea]]n rebellion narrative may be the earliest example of Lianhuanhua. In 1899, Wenyi Book Company in [[Shanghai]] published the illustrated [[lithograph]] ''"The Story of the Three Kingdoms"'' drawn by Zhu Zhixuan. The format then was called ''"huihui tu"'' or chapter pictures.<ref name="Lent" />
In 1916 [[Caobao Road (Shanghai Metro)|Caobao]] newspapers bound the pictures to attract a larger audience base of middle and lower class readers. The rise of Lianhuanhua's popularity was proportional to the rise of [[lithographic]] printing introduced to Shanghai from the West.<ref name="Lent" /> [[Shanghai]] comics journals in the 1920s featured more artwork, typically depicting traditional stories along the lines of [[Chinese mythology]] or [[Chinese folklore]]. Small publishers in the 1920s and 1930s were mostly located on a street called Beigongyili in the [[Zhabei]] district. In 1935 street book stall owners and publishers established the "Shanghai Lianhuan Tuhua Promotion Society" at [[Taoyuanli]].<ref name="Lent" /> The illustrated stories were originally targeted to children and marginally literate readers.<ref name="Wendy" />
The books could be rented for a small fee in street [[kiosk]]s. By the 1920s, lianhuanhua were also found in [[Hong Kong]]. These rental stores were common even during the [[Japanese occupation of Hong Kong|Japanese occupation]] periods in the 1940s.<ref name="Wendy" />
In Hong Kong during the 1970s, the format had essentially disappeared as they had become materials associated with the uneducated and unsophisticated.<ref name="Wendy" />
Though lianhuanhua production decreased in mainland China during [[Cultural Revolution]], many books were still produced.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lianhuanhua 连环画 - Picture Storybook|url=http://digicoll.manoa.hawaii.edu/storybook/index.php?c=1|website=University of Hawaii Digital Collection|accessdate=19 April 2017}}</ref> From the late 1970s to the early 1980s, lianhuanhua made a major comeback. As in previous eras of lianhuanhua production, many of the books were adaptations of other films or television shows.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stember|first1=Nick|title=Chinese Lianhuanhua: A Century of Pirated Movies|url=http://www.nickstember.com/chinese-lianhuanhua-century-of-pirated-movies/|accessdate=19 April 2017}}</ref>
During and after the Cultural Revolution, the communist party adopted the medium for [[propaganda]] and education purposes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Propaganda and ideology in everyday life: Chinese comic books - Asian and African studies blog|url=http://blogs.bl.uk/asian-and-african/2015/05/propaganda-and-ideology-in-everyday-life-chinese-comic-books.html|website=blogs.bl.uk|language=en}}</ref>
From the late 1980s to the 1990s, demand for lianhuanhua decreased dramatically, and today, comic books such as [[manhua]] and translations of Japanese [[manga]] are much more popular than lianhuanhua.<ref>China.org.cn. "[http://china.org.cn/english/LI-e/26574.htm]." ''Allure of illustrated booklets.'' Retrieved on 2011-12-13.</ref>
Not long ago, Renmin Meishu Chubanshe (People's Fine Arts Publishing House), Shanghai Renmin Meishu Chubanshe (Shanghai People's Fine Arts Publishing House) and Tianjin People's Renmin Meishu Chubanshe (Tianjin People's Fine Arts Publishing House) have republished some of their popular Lianhuanhua books.
==Present== Currently there is a resurgent interest in this format. The [[Shanghai Museum of Art]] has inaugurated a permanent exhibition of Lianhuanhua as a popular [[grassroots]] [[fine art]] form.
==See also== * [[Comic strip]] * [[Manhua]] * [[Chinese art]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * 阿英：《''中国连环图画史话 (History of Lianhuanhua in China)》. 山东画报出版社, Aug 2008. {{ISBN|978-7-80713-490-9}}. * {{cite web |author=Lent, John A |title =Lianhuanhua | url =http://www2.eca.usp.br/nonaarte/ojs/index.php/nonaarte/article/view/15 | publisher = [[ECA-USP]] | date = September 2012}} * {{cite web |author= Martin, R. Orion|title = Lianhuanhua: China’s Pulp Comics | url = http://www.tcj.com/lianhuanhua-chinas-pulp-comics/ | publisher = [[The Comics Journal]]| date = 17 October 2014}} *"Linked Pictures: A Genre of Chinese Illustrated Books", by Minjie Chen, 19 June 2015.<ref>https://blogs.princeton.edu/cotsen/2015/06/chinese-illustrated-books/</ref> *"Chinese Lianhuanhua: A Century of Pirated Movies", by Nick Stember, 23 May 2014.<ref>http://www.nickstember.com/chinese-lianhuanhua-century-of-pirated-movies/</ref>
==Lists== * [[Lianhuanhua listed by year]]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050124022137/http://english.eastday.com/epublish/gb/paper1/455/class000100006/hwz54899.htm History of Lianhuanhua] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070427121218/http://kaladarshan.arts.ohio-state.edu/exhib/ccomic/comindx.html Lianhuanhua Pictures] * [https://blogs.princeton.edu/cotsen/2015/06/chinese-illustrated-books/ Lianhuanhua Collection at the Cotsen Library, Princeton University] * [http://digicoll.manoa.hawaii.edu/storybook/index.php Lian Huan Hua (连环画) Collection, Asia Collection, Hamilton Library, University of Hawaii at Manoa]
{{Manhua}} {{Comics}}
