page.title: List of Latin Grammy Awards categories

revision.text:
The '''[[Latin Grammy Awards]]''' are awarded in a series of '''categories''', each of which isolate a specific contribution to [[Latin music (genre)|Latin music]]. The standard awards list nominees in each category from which a winner is selected. These categories have been added and removed over time.
==General Field== The General Field consists of four standard awards representing the best over-all achievements in performance, production, and songwriting in [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] languages: *[[Latin Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]] is awarded to the performer and the production team of a single song. *[[Latin Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]] is awarded to the performer and the production team of a full album. *[[Latin Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] is awarded to the writer(s)/composer(s) of a single song. *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] is awarded to an artist without reference to a song or album.
==Genre-specific fields== ===Pop=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Pop Vocal Album|Best Contemporary Pop Vocal Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Traditional Pop Vocal Album|Best Traditional Pop Vocal Album]]
''Previously awarded:'' *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Album|Best Female Pop Vocal Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Album|Best Male Pop Vocal Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Pop Album by a Duo or Group with Vocals|Best Pop Album by a Duo or Group with Vocals]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album|Best Pop Vocal Album]]
===Urban=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Urban Fusion/Performance|Best Urban Fusion/Performance]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Urban Music Album|Best Urban Music Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Urban Song|Best Urban Song]]
===Rock=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Rock Album|Best Rock Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Rock Song|Best Rock Song]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Pop/Rock Album|Best Pop/Rock Album]]
''Previously awarded:'' *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Rock Solo Vocal Album|Best Rock Solo Vocal Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Rock Vocal Album, Duo or Group|Best Rock Vocal Album, Duo or Group]]
===Alternative=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Alternative Song|Best Alternative Song]]
===Tropical=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Salsa Album|Best Salsa Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Cumbia/Vallenato Album|Best Cumbia/Vallenato Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Tropical Album|Best Contemporary Tropical Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Traditional Tropical Album|Best Traditional Tropical Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Tropical Fusion Album|Best Tropical Fusion Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Tropical Song|Best Tropical Song]]
''Previously awarded:'' *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Merengue Album|Best Merengue Album]]
===Singer-Songwriter=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Singer-Songwriter Album|Best Singer-Songwriter Album]]
===Regional Mexican=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Ranchero/Mariachi Album|Best Ranchero/Mariachi Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Banda Album|Best Banda Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Tejano Album|Best Tejano Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Norteño Album|Best Norteño Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Regional Mexican Song|Best Regional Mexican Song]]
''Previously awarded:'' *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Grupero Album|Best Grupero Album]]
===Instrumental=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Instrumental Album|Best Instrumental Album]]
===Traditional=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album|Best Folk Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Tango Album|Best Tango Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Flamenco Album|Best Flamenco Album]]
===Jazz=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Latin Jazz Album|Best Latin Jazz Album]]
===Christian=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Christian Album (Spanish Language)|Best Christian Album (Spanish Language)]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Christian Album (Portuguese Language)|Best Christian Album (Portuguese Language)]]
===Portuguese Language === *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Portuguese Language Contemporary Pop Album|Best Portuguese Language Contemporary Pop Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Portuguese Language Rock or Alternative Album|Best Portuguese Language Rock or Alternative Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Samba/Pagode Album|Best Samba/Pagode Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best MPB Album|Best MPB Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Sertaneja Music Album|Best Sertaneja Music Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Portuguese Language Roots Album|Best Portuguese Language Roots Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Portuguese Language Song|Best Portuguese Language Song]]
''Previously awarded:'' *Best Romantic Music Album
Note: The field was originally called "Brazilian" before it was changed to "Portuguese Language" in 2016.
===Children's=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Latin Children’s Album|Best Latin Children’s Album]]
===Classical=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Classical Album|Best Classical Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Classical Contemporary Composition|Best Classical Contemporary Composition]]
===Arrangement=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Arrangement|Best Arrangement]]
===Recording Package=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Recording Package|Best Recording Package]]
===Production=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Engineered Album|Best Engineered Album]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Producer of the Year|Producer of the Year]]
===Music video=== *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Short Form Music Video|Best Short Form Music Video]] *[[Latin Grammy Award for Best Long Form Music Video|Best Long Form Music Video]]
==Special awards== There are special awards which are awarded without nominations, typically for achievements of longer than the past year, which the standard awards apply to:
*[[Latin Recording Academy Person of the Year|Person of the Year]] is a Special Merit Award presented to an individual who has had a significant effect on [[Latin music (genre)|Latin music]] and has taken part in extensive philanthropy. *[[Latin Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award|Lifetime Achievement Award]]: is a Special Merit Award presented to performers who have made creative contributions of outstanding artistic significance to the field of recording during their careers. *[[Latin Grammy Trustees Award|Trustees Awards]]: is a Special Merit Award presented to individuals who have made significant contributions, other than performance, to the field of recording during their careers. *[[Latin Grammy Hall of Fame Award|Hall of Fame Award]] honors recordings that are at least twenty-five years old that have made significant contributions
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100926192400/http://latingrammy.com/en/pages/11-awards The Latin GRAMMY Award Categories] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100214061826/http://www.latingrammy.com/en/pages/12-awards The Latin GRAMMY Award Category Guidelines] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110713190418/http://www.latingrammy.com/en/pages/13-awards The Latin GRAMMY Special Awards]
{{Latin Grammy Awards}} {{Latin Grammy Awards categories}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Latin Grammy Awards categories}} [[Category:Latin Grammy Awards|.]] [[Category:Music-related lists]] [[Category:Latin Grammy Award categories| ]] [[Category:American music-related lists]]

page.title: List of video games considered artistic

revision.comment: /* 2016 onward */ adding RDR2 from NYTimes piece
revision.text:
{{Expand list|date=August 2008}} This is a '''list of video games considered to be works of art'''. Although several countries offer legal protections to all video games that are similar or identical to protections offered to other artistic works, and although by this standard all [[Video games as an art form|video games can be considered as art]], this article lists games that are specifically identified by art critics and video game reviewers as works of art.
==20th century==
<!-- Only include games that have been described by reliable sources to be works of art, and provide a reference for the source. --> *''[[Tempest (video game)|Tempest]]'' (1981) – an arcade [[tube shooter]] with [[vector monitor|vector graphics]] by [[Atari Inc]]. [[PBS]] Idea Channel described it as a strongly aesthetic experience, comparing it to paintings.<ref name="ideachannel"/> *''[[Super Mario Bros.]]'' (1985 [[NES]]) – a side-scrolling platform game released as a launch title for the NES and became the most praised game in the original Mario series for its 8-bit visuals, power-ups and charm. The game has its own spot in the Smithsonian museum in an exhibition called the Art of Video Games.<ref>[http://americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/featuredgames/]</ref> *The [[Myst (series)|''Myst'' series]], beginning in 1993 with ''[[Myst]]'' – a graphic adventure based on pre-rendered scenarios and a strongly atmospheric, immersive setting.<ref>{{cite web|author=|date=|url=http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3135149&p=1|title=Myst IV: Revelation Review|publisher=[[1UP.com]]|accessdate=2008-11-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614200859/http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3135149|archivedate=2006-06-14|df=}}</ref><ref name="riven rapt">{{cite web|author=Miller, Laura|date=1997-11-06|url=http://archive.salon.com/21st/feature/1997/11/cov_06riven.html|title=Riven Rapt|publisher=[[Salon.com|Salon]]|accessdate=2008-04-07|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080402053903/http://archive.salon.com/21st/feature/1997/11/cov_06riven.html <!--Added by H3llBot-->|archivedate=2008-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Rothstein, Edward|date=1994-12-04|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F07E7DD1030F937A35751C1A962958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=1|title=A New Art Form May Arise From the 'Myst'|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2008-12-01}}</ref> The level of detail allowed by the use of [[CD-ROM]] as the storage media was a technical achievement at the time, praised for the way the limitations of the format were overcome and used as part of the game story.<ref name="mysty">{{cite book|author=Smith, Greg|year=2002|title=Hop on Pop: The Pleasures and Politics of Popular Culture|series=Navigating Myst-y Landscapes: Killer Applications and Hybrid Criticism|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=0-8223-2737-6}}</ref> *''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'' (1993) – a violent game whose transgressive thrills make it, according to ''[[The Guardian]]'' games editor Keith Stewart, "natural heir to the [[splatter film|splatterhouse cinema]] of the pre-digital era".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-07-06-22-years-on-doom-retains-the-ability-to-shock|last=Stewart|first=Keith|title=22 years on, Doom retains the ability to shock|work=Eurogamer}}</ref> *''[[Chrono Trigger]]'' (1995) – a [[Japanese role-playing game]] created by [[Square Enix]] about a group of adventurers from different time periods trying to stop the end of the world. The game has been praised for its multi-ending plot, graphics, art direction by [[Akira Toriyama]], and soundtrack by [[Yasunori Mitsuda]].<ref>http://www.production-ig.com/contents/works/07_/000133.html</ref><ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20060325111040/http://www.playmagazine.com/index.php?fuseaction=SiteMain.showGamePage&Game_ID=169</ref><ref>http://kotaku.com/5546807/a-visual-guide-to-the-role+playing-game</ref><ref>http://www.pcworld.com/article/2017821/game-on-at-the-art-museum.html</ref><ref>http://wii.ign.com/articles/117/1170454p1.html</ref><ref>http://www.rpgfan.com/reviews/chronotrigger/Chrono_Trigger-6.html</ref><ref>http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages2/563538.asp</ref><ref>http://www.chronocompendium.com/Term/Supporting_Material_Translation.html#Chrono_Trigger_Gamest_Coverage</ref> *''[[Cosmology of Kyoto]]'' (1995) – an [[open world]] graphic adventure exploring [[Japanese mythology|Japanese myths]] in ancient [[Kyoto]]. Together with ''Myst'', it was reviewed by film critic [[Roger Ebert]] in a column on [[#Roger Ebert on video games as art|whether video games can be art]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.suntimes.com/ebert/2010/07/okay_kids_play_on_my_lawn.html |work=Chicago Sun-Times |title=Okay, kids, play on my lawn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811003526/http://blogs.suntimes.com/ebert/2010/07/okay_kids_play_on_my_lawn.html |archivedate=August 11, 2010 }} "In my actual experience, I have played ''Cosmology of Kyoto'', which I enormously enjoyed, and ''[[Myst]]'', for which I lacked the patience."</ref> *''[[Final Fantasy VII]]'' (1997, PlayStation) – considered by many to be one of the best [[role-playing video game]]s, its story includes the death of a major character, aimed to give the player an emotional stake in the game.<ref name="ideachannel"/> *''[[Grim Fandango]]'' (1998, [[LucasArts]], Microsoft Windows) – An adventure game which combines elements of [[film noir]] with aspects of [[Aztec religion|Aztec mythology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gamescanbeart.com/2010/03/25/grim-fandango// |title=Archived copy |accessdate=January 25, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130910000800/http://gamescanbeart.com/2010/03/25/grim-fandango/ |archivedate=September 10, 2013 }}</ref> *''[[The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time]]'' (1998, [[Nintendo]], Nintendo 64) – An [[action-adventure game]] that revolutionized the entire 3D [[video game industry]]. It was highly praised for its music, gameplay and its technical achievements for the time. It is widely considered as the [[Greatest games of all time|greatest game of all time]]. *''[[Planescape: Torment]]'' (1999, [[Black Isle Studios]], Microsoft Windows) – A cult-classic [[role-playing video game]] that was praised for its detailed writing, defined characters, unique setting and the use of death to progress the story.<ref>{{cite web|title=GAME THEORY; A Universe Where Ideas Can Trump Actions|author=Seth Schiesel|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/27/technology/game-theory-a-universe-where-ideas-can-trump-actions.html}} "''Plane scape could well herald a new wave of games that are valued as much for their artistic merit as they are for their technical brilliance and the fun they offer.''"</ref> *''[[Vib Ribbon]]'' (1999, [[NanaOn-Sha]], PlayStation) – a [[rhythm game]] known for its unique [[vector graphics]] artstyle. ''Vib Ribbon'' was collected as part of [[List of video games in the Museum of Modern Art|a video game exhibit]] at the [[Museum of Modern Art]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Masaya Matsuura. Vib-Ribbon. 1997-1999|work=MoMA|url=http://www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?object_id=162460}}</ref>
==2000–2005==
<!-- Only include games that have been described by reliable sources to be works of art, and provide a reference for the source or the entry will be removed. --> *''[[Galatea (video game)|Galatea]]'' (2000, Microsoft Windows) – [[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]] analyzes it as an art game saying that it "transcends that", and calls it "literature" and "not an art game [but] a game about art".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2009/07/20/letters-of-love-galatea/|title=Letters Of Love: Galatea|publisher=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]}}</ref> *''[[Max Payne (video game)|Max Payne]]'' (2001, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux, Xbox, PlayStation 2) – a third-person shooter developed by [[Remedy Entertainment]]. The game was praised for its use of [[neo-noir]] storytelling devices<ref>{{cite web|title=Are Video Games Art?|first=Aaron|last=Smuts|url=http://www.contempaesthetics.org/newvolume/pages/article.php?articleID=299}}</ref> and its thematic connection and frequent references to [[Norse mythology]] *''[[Silent Hill 2]]'' (2001, Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 2, PlayStation 3 (HD), Xbox, Xbox 360 (HD)) – [[Team Silent]]'s survivor horror video game has been considered a work of art due to its story; atmosphere; sound design; exploration of psychological ideas such as subconscious; use of psychological horror, of metaphors, of taboo topics such as incest and domestic violence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esotericarticles.com/Silent_Hill_2_Themes_Analysis.html|title=Silent Hill 2 Themes Analysis|work=Esoteric Articles}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jayisanerd.wordpress.com/2013/01/28/silent-hill-2-thematic-analysis/|title=Silent Hill 2 Thematic Analysis|date=January 28, 2013|work=Games and Things}}</ref> *''[[Ico]]'' (2001, PlayStation 2) – a title created by [[Team Ico]] that has often been cited as an example of art in games due to its immersive gameplay, evoking narrative and unique style.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/3358016/Why-videogamers-are-artists-at-heart.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Tom | last=Hoggins | title=Why videogamers are artists at heart | date=24 July 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E05E1D81F38F936A25752C1A9679C8B63 | work=The New York Times | first=Charles | last=Herold | title=GAME THEORY; To Play Emperor or God, or Grunt in a Tennis Skirt | date=15 November 2001}}</ref><ref> {{cite web|url=http://archive.gamespy.com/reviews/october01/ico/index.shtm |title=GameSpy.com - Reviews: ICO (PS2) |publisher=[[GameSpy]] |date=2008-10-21 |accessdate=2012-11-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081021085522/http://archive.gamespy.com/reviews/october01/ico/index.shtm |archivedate=October 21, 2008 }}</ref> *''[[Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty]]'' (2001, PlayStation 2) – a [[stealth game]] by [[Hideo Kojima]] that has been cited as a primary example of artistic expression in video games and an early example of [[post-modernism]] in video games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digra.org/dl/db/05150.07598.pdf |title=Microsoft Word - 34. How Games Express Ideas |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.games.ign.com/articles/809/809655p1.html |title=Top 10 Tuesday: Games as Art - IGN |publisher=Uk.games.ign.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216210036/http://uk.games.ign.com/articles/809/809655p1.html |archivedate=2009-12-16 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/flashback-how-metal-gear-solid-2-foretold-our-post-truth-future-w450421|title=Flashback: How 'Metal Gear Solid 2' Foretold Our Post-Truth Future|date=November 14, 2016|author=Alex Wiltshire|accessdate=April 8, 2017|website=rollingstone.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-08-16-metal-gear-solid-2-the-first-postmodern-video-game|title= Metal Gear Solid 2: The first postmodern video game|date=August 16, 2015|accessdate=April 8, 2017|website=eurogamer.net|author=Rich Stanton}}</ref> *''[[MusicVR]]'' (2002-2004, Microsoft Windows) – a series of two video games, [[Tres Lunas (video game)|''Tres Lunas'']] (2002) and [[Maestro (video game)|''Maestro'']] (2004), under the creative design of English musician [[Mike Oldfield]]. Each one set out to be a real-time virtual reality experience combining imagery and music, as a non-violent and essentially a non-goal driven game. *''[[Yume Nikki]]'' (2005, Microsoft Windows)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://littlebobeep.com/2010/yume-nikki-1-boxart-is-a-fake-idea/ |title=Yume Nikki 1: Boxart is a Fake Idea |publisher=Littlebobeep.com |date=2010-01-05 |accessdate=2012-11-15}}</ref> – An independently-developed freeware game that has the player explore the dreams of a [[hikikomori]] little girl known only as "Madotsuki" as she encounters numerous surreal characters and events while collecting "Effects", most of which do little more than alter her appearance. *''[[The Endless Forest]]'' (2005, Microsoft Windows)<ref name=wemakemoney>{{cite web|author=Regine|url=http://www.we-make-money-not-art.com/archives/2006/06/michael-auriea.php |title=Interview of Michael Samyn & Auriea Harvey |publisher=we make money not art |date=June 20, 2006 |accessdate=October 20, 2011}}</ref> – Originally commissioned for an art exhibition, ''The Endless Forest'' is an MMO in the broader sense of the word. As a stag, the player roams around the forest and interact with other players; though not by words, but by sounds and body language. Another unique feature is that all players are recognizable by their unique symbol and customized appearance, but are otherwise anonymous.
==2006–2010==
<!-- Only include games that have been described by reliable sources to be works of art, and provide a reference for the source or the entry will be removed. --> *''[[Ōkami]]'' (2006, PlayStation 2) – An adventure game based on Japanese mythology, the game's graphics were designed to appear similar to [[sumi-e]] watercolor paintings, and incorporated art-based brushstrokes by the player to execute special moves.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.1up.com/previews/okami_6 | title = Preview - Okami | date = 16 September 2005 | accessdate = 27 June 2012 | first = Jane | last = Picknard | publisher = IGN }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.wired.com/culture/design/commentary/games/2006/10/71986 | title = The Game of Art | first = Clive | last = Thompson | date = 23 October 2006 | accessdate = 27 June 2012 | work = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] }}</ref> *''[[Shadow of the Colossus]]'' (2006, PlayStation 2) – a title created by [[Team Ico]] that is a [[spiritual successor]] and prequel to ''[[Ico]]''. The game is regarded as an important work of art due to its minimalist landscape designs, strong aesthetic, immersive gameplay, powerful narrative and emotional journey. ''Shadow of the Colossus'' has been referenced numerous times in debates regarding art and video games.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.suntimes.com/ebert/2010/07/okay_kids_play_on_my_lawn.html |work=Chicago Sun-Times |title=Okay, kids, play on my lawn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811003526/http://blogs.suntimes.com/ebert/2010/07/okay_kids_play_on_my_lawn.html |archivedate=August 11, 2010 }}</ref> *''[[Mother 3]]'' (2006, Game Boy Advance) – the sequel to ''Earthbound'', known as ''Mother 2'' in Japan, it is a Japanese RPG about the story of one of the twins as he, his pet dog and his friends fight out an invading force. The game has been praised for its in depth narrative and made well use of its 16-bit graphics.<ref name="actionbutton.net">{{Cite web|title = mother 3 (****) {{!}} action button dot net|url = http://www.actionbutton.net/?p=422|website = www.actionbutton.net|access-date = 2016-02-09}}</ref> The game is also heavy with themes including the importance of a mother, moral fungibility, and dualisms such as nature and technology, and feudalism and capitalism, and is frequently compared to a form of literature.<ref name="actionbutton.net"/><ref>{{Cite web|title = Hardcore Gaming 101: Mother 3|url = http://www.hardcoregaming101.net/mother/mother3.htm|website = www.hardcoregaming101.net|access-date = 2016-02-09}}</ref> Despite never officially being released outside of Japan, it was later fan translated by the group of Earthbound fans, it and its predecessor served as inspiration to several other games including ''[[Yume Nikki]]'' and ''[[Undertale]]''. *''[[Dwarf Fortress]]'' (2006, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux) – A [[roguelike]], [[city-building game]] where the player creates an expansive world each play-through, allowing them to envision the history and culture for their civilization each time around.<ref name="ideachannel"/> *''[[BioShock]]'' (2007, Microsoft Windows, Xbox 360, Mac OS, Cloud (OnLive), PlayStation 3) – a title created by [[Irrational Games]] then known as 2K Boston, that is a [[spiritual successor]] to ''[[System Shock 2]]''. The game is regarded as an important work of art due to its immersive atmosphere, compelling storytelling{{According to whom|date=January 2015}} and the narrative deconstruction of linear gameplay.<ref>{{cite book|last=Creeber|first=Martin|title=Digital Culture: Understanding New Media|year=2008|publisher=Open University Press|isbn=0-335-22197-1}}</ref> *''[[Portal (video game)|Portal]]'' (2007, PC, Xbox 360, Mac OS, Linux, PlayStation 3) – a puzzle game developed by [[Valve Corporation]], involving the use of portals to transport the player through space. The game was praised for its innovative mechanics, narrative and storytelling, and writing, especially praising the character of [[GLaDOS]].<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Art-Video-Games-Pac-Man-Effect/dp/159962110X The Art of Video Games: From Pac-Man to Mass Effect]</ref><ref>[http://gamestudies.org/1202/articles/the_algorithmic_experience The Algorithmic Experience: Portal as Art]</ref> This game recently became featured as part of the [[Museum of Modern Art]] exhibit "Applied Design".<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?object_id=162463|title = Valve, Portal|publisher = Museum of Modern Art|website = The Collection|accessdate = 26 March 2014}}</ref> *''[[Fallout 3]]'' (2008, PC, Xbox 360, PlayStation 3) – [[Action role-playing game]] acclaimed for its [[steampunk]] / [[Retrofuturism|retrofuturistic]] design and credible reconstruction and visuals of [[Apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic fiction|post-apocalyptic]] [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/article/2008/10/31/fallout-3-behind-art/|title=''Fallout 3'': Behind the art|author=Samantha Xu|date=October 31, 2008|accessdate=April 8, 2017}}</ref> In 2012, ''Fallout 3'' was also exhibited in ''[[The Art of Video Games]]'', at [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/featuredgames/|title=The Art of Video Games|website=americanart.si.edu|accessdate=December 4, 2016}}</ref> *''[[Braid (video game)|Braid]]'' (2008, PC, Xbox 360, Mac OS, Linux, PlayStation 3) – a puzzle-platform game developed by [[Number None]], which uses time manipulation as its core mechanic. The game is notable for its painterly art style, layered philosophical narrative, and unique approach to game design.<ref>[http://blogs.bloodedbythought.org/m2tw/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Gamasutra_The-Art-Of-Braid_Creating-A-Visual-Identity-For-An-Unusual-Game.pdf The Art Of Braid: Creating A Visual Identity For An Unusual Game]</ref><ref>[http://www.nohighscores.com/2012/06/22/braid-its-art-but-is-it-a-game/ Braid: It's Art, but is it a Game?]</ref> *''[[Flower (video game)|Flower]]'' (2009, PlayStation 3) – Developed by [[thatgamecompany]], the player "controls" a gust of wind through [[Sixaxis|motion controls]], guiding it to various flowers around a landscape to gather petals. The gameplay was designed to provoke an emotional response from the player, and was chosen as one of the games shown at [[The Art of Video Games]] exhibit at the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/winninggames.pdf |title=The Art of Video Games Voting Result |date=2011-05-05 |accessdate=2011-05-05 |publisher=[[The Smithsonian Institution]]}}</ref> *''[[The Path (video game)|The Path]]'' (2009, Mac OS X, Microsoft Windows) - Visionary reflection about the loss of childhood innocence between fable and horror.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kotaku.com/5234167/the-path-for-art-games|title=The Path For Art Games|last=Crecente|first=Brian|work=Kotaku|access-date=2017-08-17|language=en-US}}</ref> *''[[Deadly Premonition]]'' (2010, Xbox 360, PlayStation 3, Microsoft Windows) – A [[survival horror]] that has been described "the strangest video game of the year" and a primary example of "games as art", praised for its "emotional range, from traditional survival horror scares to farcical comedy".<ref>[http://www.metro.co.uk/tech/games/845905-games-review-deadly-premonition-is-one-of-a-kind Games review - Deadly Premonition is one of a kind | Metro.co.uk<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *''[[Heavy Rain]]'' (2010, PlayStation 3) – An [[interactive movie]] where the player enters [[quick time event]]s during various sequences, including intense, rapid-paced scenes. The results of the player's choices or actions can cause one of the four main characters to die while the story continues on, causing the player to become invested in the game's story.<ref name="ideachannel">{{cite video | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IAs4Dy-lh8E | title = Idea Channel: Top 5 Most Artful Video Games | publisher = [[PBS]] | date = 23 January 2013 | accessdate = 28 January 2013 | first = Mike | last = Rugnetta }}</ref> *''[[Amnesia: The Dark Descent]]'' (2010, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux, OnLive) – A survival horror game praised for its horror elements, particularly its atmosphere and sound, with many critics regarding it as one of their scariest experiences.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://gamecult.umwblogs.org/2013/02/14/can-horror-and-art-coincide-a-close-reading-playing-of-amnesia-the-dark-descent/ |title=Can Horror and Art Coincide? A Close Reading (Playing) of Amnesia: the Dark Descent|date=February 14, 2013|author= Savannah |work=Games and Culture}}</ref>
==2011–2015==
<!-- Only include games that have been described by reliable sources to be works of art, and provide a reference for the source or the entry will be removed. --> *''[[Child of Eden]]'' (2011, Xbox 360, PlayStation 3) – Similar to ''[[Rez]]'', a game made to evoke the feeling of synesthesia.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/30/arts/video-games/child-of-eden-video-game-is-a-sensory-trip-to-paradise.html | title = Sensory Trip to a Paradise on Screen | first = Scott | last = Schiesel | date = 29 July 2011 | accessdate = 27 June 2012 | work = [[New York Times]] }}</ref> *''[[The Cat and the Coup]]'' (2011, Microsoft Windows)<ref>Rose, Michael. ''[http://www.indiegames.com/2010/10/indiecade_2010_finalists_the_c.html]''</ref> – A documentary video game about the life of [[Mohammad Mosaddegh]], former Prime Minister of Iran. *''[[Dear Esther]]'' (2012, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux)<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://store.steampowered.com/app/203810|title = Dear Esther on Steam|accessdate = 25 March 2014}}</ref> – a first person video game centered around its graphical environment and story. The narrative is provided through monologues as the player journeys through the environment.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/video-games/video-game-reviews/9115437/Dear-Esther-review.html|title = Dear Esther review|date = 5 March 2012|accessdate = 25 March 2014|publisher = The Daily Telegraph|first = Tom|last = Hoggins}}</ref> *''[[Journey (2012 video game)|Journey]]'' (2012, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4); Developed by [[thatgamecompany]], this game has been described as an emotional experience, due to its immersive setting, distinctive visual style, and de-emphasized gameplay.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gamesblog/2012/mar/15/journey-game-or-interactive-art | title = Is Journey a game or a piece of interactive art? | first = Keith | last = Stuart | date = 15 March 2012 | accessdate = 26 March 2013 | work = [[The Guardian]]}}</ref> *''[[The Unfinished Swan]]'' (2012, PS3, PS4, PS Vita) - The game starts with a completely white space in which the player, a boy named Monroe, is chasing after a swan that has escaped a painting. The player has to splat gobs of black paint to draw and materialize the world around.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/the-unfinished-swan-review/1900-6415945/|title=The Unfinished Swan Review|last=Clark|first=Justin|date=2014-11-06|website=GameSpot|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-17}}</ref> See also this [http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/the-unfinished-swan-review-a-beautiful-piece-of-art-wrapped-in-the-guise-of-an-interactive-fairy-tale/ review.] *''[[Spec Ops: The Line]]'' (2012, Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360) – A third person shooter created by [[Yager]] that deconstructs the "[[Shooter game|shooter genre]]". Inspired by [[Joseph Conrad]]'s ''[[Heart of Darkness]]'', ''Spec Ops: The Line'' dwells heavily on themes of moral ambiguity, as the player finds themselves struggling to justify their actions in the plot.<ref>[http://www.penny-arcade.com/patv/episode/spec-ops-the-line-part-1 Spec Ops: The Line (Part 1)]</ref><ref>[http://www.penny-arcade.com/patv/episode/spec-ops-the-line-part-2 Spec Ops: The Line (Part 2)]</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.critical-distance.com/2012/11/20/spec-ops-the-line/ | title=Spec Ops: The Line | work=Critical Distance | date=20 November 2012 | accessdate=2 July 2016 | author=Keogh, Brendan}}</ref> *''[[The Walking Dead (video game)|The Walking Dead]]'' (2012, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, PlayStation Vita, iOS, Android) – An [[adventure game]] set in the world of [[Robert Kirkman]]'s acclaimed [[The Walking Dead (comic book)|comic book series]], ''The Walking Dead'' has been praised for its story, meaningful player decisions, and believable characters. It is often considered one of the greatest examples of storytelling in video games.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamesradar.com/the-walking-dead-review/ |accessdate = 6 December 2014|title = The Walking Dead game review|publisher = GamesRadar|first = Hollander|last = Cooper|date = 26 November 2012}}</ref> *''[[The Cat Lady]]'' (2012, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux, PS4, Xbox One) - a horror point-and-click adventure game about depression, death, friendship, suicide, etc. with an underground graphic style.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://adventuregamers.com/articles/view/23373|title=The Cat Lady Review|last=|first=|date=|access-date=2017-07-31|newspaper=Adventure Gamers}}</ref> *''[[Beyond: Two Souls]]'' (2013, PlayStation 3) – Tells the story of Jodie, who possesses supernatural powers through a psychic link to Aiden, a bodiless entity, growing from adolescence to adulthood while learning to control Aiden and the powers they share.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/technology/gaming/game-reviews/beyond-two-souls-more-like-a-blockbuster-sci-fi-movie-than-a-game/article14740477/ | title = 'Beyond: Two Souls' more like a blockbuster sci-fi movie than a game | work = [[The Globe and Mail]] | first = Peter | last = Nowak | date = 8 October 2013 | accessdate = 27 September 2015 }}</ref> *''[[BioShock Infinite]]'' (2013, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Xbox 360, PlayStation 3) – A first-person shooter set in 1912 in an alternate universe where [[American Exceptionalism]] is flourishing aboard the flying city, Columbia. The game's narrative challenges concepts of nationalism, religion and racism prevalent during that period, as to provide a "funhouse mirror of American ideological history", according to Ben Popper of [[The Verge]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2013/4/2/4170256/bioshock-infinite-making-great-art-from-americas-racist-past-and | title = 'BioShock Infinite' makes great art from America's racist past and political present | first = Ben | last = Popper | date = 2013-04-02 | accessdate = 2013-04-02 | publisher = [[The Verge]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/26/arts/video-games/bioshock-infinite-irrationals-new-video-game.html | title = BioShock’s Latest: Civil War in a City in the Sky | first = Chris | last = Suellentrop | date = 2013-03-25 | accessdate = 2013-04-02 | work = [[New York Times]] }}</ref> *''[[Grand Theft Auto V]]'' (2013, Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, Xbox 360, Xbox One) – [[Rockstar Games]]' open world crime-based title satirizes the modern day lifestyle of the West Coast of the United States, taking place in a city that is a smaller-scale but detailed interpretation of the city of [[Los Angeles]] and its surrounding areas, often used by players and artists as a backdrop for their own creations.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2013/sep/27/grand-theft-auto-digital-art | title = Grand Theft Auto: meet the grand masters of digital art | first = Jonathan | last = Jones | date = 27 September 2013 | accessdate = 3 May 2016 | work = [[The Guardian]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/video-games/10315566/GTA-5-the-video-game-that-gives-you-the-world.html | title = GTA 5: the video game that gives you the world | first = Mic | last= Wright | date = 13 September 2013 | accessdate = 3 May 2016 | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] }}</ref> *''[[The Last of Us]]'' (2013, PlayStation 3) – A game set in the aftermath of a zombie apocalypse, the [[Naughty Dog]]-developed title has been stated to be "a masterful marriage of storytelling and game design" and considered the "most riveting, emotionally resonant story-driven epic of [the seventh] console generation".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.computerandvideogames.com/410928/the-last-of-us-review-round-up-easily-naughty-dogs-finest-moment/ | title = The Last of Us review round-up: 'Easily Naughty Dog's finest moment' | first = Tamoor | last = Hussain |date = 5 June 2013 | accessdate = 30 June 2013 | publisher = [[Computer and Video Games]] }}</ref> *''[[Papers, Please]]'' (2013, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux) – a [[border control]] [[simulation game]] where a political uprising plot develops in the background of mechanical, [[Grinding (video gaming)|grinding]] gameplay that mimics the mechanical, repetitive work of an [[immigration officer]] in a fictional country, presenting the player with ethical and moral choices between job and family.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2013/08/papers-please-review-paper-trail-of-tears/ | title=Papers, Please Review: Paper trail of tears | publisher=[[Ars Technica]] | accessdate=15 August 2013 | author=Sam Machkovech}}</ref> *''[[Proteus (video game)|Proteus]]'' (2013, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux, PlayStation 3, PlayStation Vita) – A procedurally generated game that allows players to explore an expanse of musical environment, where every creature and plant has its own unique musical signature to accompany it, resulting in changes according to where players explore.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://ign.com/articles/2013/02/09/proteus-review|title = Proteus Review|publisher = IGN|date = 8 February 2013|accessdate = 25 March 2014|first = Nathan|last = Grayson}}</ref> *''[[Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons]]'' (2013, PS3, PC, Xbox 360) – A story driven game praised for its story, gameplay and experience which it provides. The game has no intelligible dialogue and provides players with a powerful story and experience.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gameplanet.com.au/xbox-360/reviews/g5216bf941cee9/Brothers-A-Tale-of-Two-Sons-review/|title = Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons review|accessdate = 25 March 2014|publisher = Gameplanet Australia|first = Joshua|last = Drummond|date = 23 August 2013|undefined = }}</ref> *''[[Gone Home]]'' (2013, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux) – An [[exploration game]] where the player takes the role of a teenaged girl returning to her unoccupied home after spending time abroad. ''Gone Home'' is praised for its narration, gameplay and atmosphere.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://business.financialpost.com/2013/08/15/gone-home-review-a-startling-and-unexpected-storytelling-triumph|accessdate = 25 March 2014|title = Gone Home review – A startling and unexpected storytelling triumph|publisher = Financial Post|first = Matthew|last = Braga|date = 15 August 2013}}</ref> *''[[The Stanley Parable]]'' (2013, Microsoft Windows, OS X, Linux) - [[Interactive fiction]] defined as a "meta-game where is not the gamer to play the game, but the game to play the gamer".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whatculture.com/gaming/why-the-stanley-parable-almost-granted-videogames-art-status|title= Why 'The Stanley Parable' Almost Granted Videogames ‘Art’ Status|website=whatculture.com|accessdate=April 8, 2017}}</ref> *''[[Papo & Yo]]'' (2013, PS3, Microsoft Windows, OS X, Linux) - It tells a personal story about love, loss, and growth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2012/08/14/papo-yo-review-psn/|title=Papo & Yo Review (PSN)|date=2012-08-14|website=PlayStation LifeStyle|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> *''[[Contrast (video game)|Contrast]]'' (2013, PS3, PS4, Xbox 360, Xbox One, Microsoft Windows) - Twilight adventure with Art Nouveau aesthetics; noirish atmosphere, varied gameplay and jazz soundtrack. {{Citation needed|date=March 2018}} *''[[The Talos Principle]]'' (2014, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux, Android, PlayStation 4) – A philosophical puzzle game, where players discovered different tradition philosophical schools through solving puzzles and discussing with NPC. *''[[The Vanishing of Ethan Carter]]'' (2014, Microsoft Windows, PS4) .<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/the-vanishing-of-ethan-carter-review/1900-6415893/|title=The Vanishing of Ethan Carter Review|last=McInnis|first=Shaun|date=2014-09-29|website=GameSpot|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mweb.co.za/games/view/tabid/4210/Article/15803/The-Vanishing-of-Ethan-Carter-Review-A-hauntingly-beautiful-masterpiece.aspx|title=The Vanishing of Ethan Carter Review: A hauntingly beautiful masterpiece|work=Gamezone|access-date=2017-08-17|language=en-US}}</ref> *''[[Valiant Hearts: The Great War]]'' (2014, Android, iOS, Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, Xbox 360, Xbox One) - Set in World War One, this game shows the stories of average soldiers on both sides and what they left behind. The game is praised for its art style, music and narration, as well as the emotions it creates within the people who play it. It also provides accurate historical information about the war which is accompanied with colorized photos. <!-- Only include games that have been described by reliable sources to be works of art, and provide a reference for the source or the entry will be removed. --> *''[[Kentucky Route Zero]]'' (2013-2018, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux) – an indie episodic point and click adventure game with the focus of the game being storytelling and a "beautiful" atmosphere. The game features a twisting, self-referential narrative,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.creativeapplications.net/games/kentucky-route-zero-mysterious-narrative-by-cardboard-computer/ |title=Kentucky Route Zero – Mysterious narrative by Cardboard Computer |first=Andrey |last=Yelbayev |date=January 18, 2013 |publisher=Creative Applications Network |accessdate=July 6, 2013}}</ref> as well as deep characterization through evocative dialogue. ''Kentucky Route Zero'' was named Game of the Year in 2013 by [[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2013/12/24/the-amazing-astonishing-rps-advent-calendar-day-24/|title=The Amazing & Astonishing RPS Advent Calendar: Day 24|last=Walker|first=John|author2=Rossignol, Jim |author3=Meer, Alec |author4=Smith, Adam |author5= Grayson, Nathan |date=24 December 2013|work=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]|accessdate=24 December 2013}}</ref> *''[[Elegy for a Dead World]]''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Khan|first1=Jahanzeb|title=Review: Elegy for a Dead World|url=http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2014/12/12/review-elegy-for-a-dead-world/122598/|website=[[Hardcore Gamer]]|publisher=Hardcore Gamer Magazine|accessdate=25 January 2015}}</ref> (2014, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux) – a [[side-scrolling]] exploration game where the player writes a [[Diary#Digital diaries|diary visible to other players]]. The player explores three worlds inspired by romantic poets [[Percy Shelley|Shelley]], [[Lord Byron|Byron]], and [[John Keats|Keats]]. While exploring, the player is prompted to make notes on their observations; notes are publicly visible via Steam Workshop. The collective note taking mechanic, representing not only an artistic game experience but also the ability of [[Nonlinear gameplay|sandbox-style games]] to support further [[Collaboration#Arts|collaborative artistic creation]] by their players, earned it an honorable mention for the Nuovo Award in the 2014 Independent Games Festival.<ref>[http://www.igf.com/02finalists.html "2014 IGF Finalists"]</ref> *''[[Beyond Eyes]]'' (2015, Microsoft Windows, OS X, Linux, Xbox One) – A game centered on a blind girl exploring her environment, where her other four senses are visualized in unique ways for the player.<ref name="ew e3 2015">{{cite web | url = http://www.ew.com/article/2015/06/19/state-videogames-art-three-scenes | title = Videogames as Art, 2015 | first = Darren | last = Franich | date = 19 June 2015 | accessdate = 19 June 2015 | work = [[Entertainment Weekly]] }}</ref> *''[[Her Story (video game)|Her Story]]'' (2015, Microsoft Windows, OS X, iOS) – A game in which the player controls a police interrogation database and must piece together how a murder occurred through entering keyword searches. The game features a unique system of storytelling.<ref>[http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/06/30/her-story-review "Her Story Review"]</ref><ref>[http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/gamers-vs-art-attitudes-video-games-like-her-story-sunset-are-killing-this-industry-1507887 "Gamers vs Art: Attitudes to video games like Her Story & Sunset are killing this industry"]</ref> *''[[The Beginner's Guide]]'' (2015, Microsoft Windows, OS X) – An exploration game by Davey Wreden, creator of ''[[The Stanley Parable]]'' in which Wreden himself narrates the player through several eccentric, uncompleted games by a recluse developer named Coda, with Wreden ascribing what these games mean about Coda's personality. The nature of the story reflects on the relationship between player and developer in modern game development, with elements of Wreden's own sudden success with ''The Stanley Parable''.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/comic-riffs/wp/2015/10/08/the-beginners-guide-to-blurring-the-lines-between-video-games-and-interactive-art/ | title = ‘The Beginners Guide’ to blurring the lines between video games and interactive art | first = Christopher | last = Byrd | date = October 8, 2015 | accessdate = October 8, 2015 | work = [[Washington Post]] }}</ref> *''[[Life Is Strange]]'' (2015, Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 4, Xbox One) – A story-driven game featuring hand-painted textures and based on a time rewind mechanic, which affects the development of the story. The game addresses the themes of surveillance, suicide and assisted suicide, as well as ontological search for defined and specific identity and coming of age.<ref>[http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2015/12/14/luis-de-miranda-writing-an-academic-paper-on-life-is-strange-is-a-genuine-experience/181969/ "Luis de Miranda: Writing an Academic Paper on Life Is Strange is a ‘Genuine Experience’"]</ref><ref>[https://medium.com/@JudgyJosh/games-as-art-life-is-strange-874cf7779c81#.70429zelp "Games as art: Life is Strange]</ref> *''[[Undertale]]'' (2015, Microsoft Windows, OS X) – A role-playing game where multiple in-game decisions by the player result in many different consequences, including, but not limited to, the actions of [[non-player character]]s, the mood and atmosphere of the game and the ending. The game's premise is built around the idea of the player choosing whether or not to kill or spare enemies, and its overarching story is held together by themes of determination, mercy and consequence. It also features an additional [[meta]]story hidden across the game's files and code.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wagner|first1=Brandon|title=‘Undertale’ Takes Next Necessary Steps for Gaming to Become Art|url=http://emorywheel.com/undertale-takes-next-necessary-steps-for-gaming-to-become-art/|website=[[The Emory Wheel]]|publisher=[[Emory University]]|date=1 December 2015|accessdate=20 January 2016|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Grayson|first1=Nathan|title=Players Still Haven't Figured Out All Of Undertale's Secrets|url=http://steamed.kotaku.com/players-still-havent-figured-out-all-of-undertales-secr-1733048190|website=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]|date=28 September 2015|accessdate=29 November 2015}}</ref> *''[[Ori and the Blind Forest]]'' (2015, Microsoft Windows, Xbox One) – A 2D open world platform game where the player controls an orphan named Ori, a white guardian spirit. This game has been critically acclaimed for its gorgeous art, touching narrative, and clever gameplay.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/technology/games/67412318/ori-and-the-blind-forest-a-gaming-work-of-art|title=Ori's masterpiece|website=Stuff|access-date=2016-04-06}}</ref>
==2016 onward==
*''[[That Dragon, Cancer]]'' (2016, Microsoft Windows, OS X) – An exploration game designed by Ryan and Amy Green designed to help share their experiences in learning and coping with the terminal cancer and death of their five-year-old son Joel.<ref name="wired">{{cite web | url = https://www.wired.com/2016/01/that-dragon-cancer/ | title = Playing for Time | first = Jason | last = Tanz | date = January 6, 2016 | accessdate = January 11, 2016 | work = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] }}</ref> *''[[Firewatch]]'' (2016, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, Microsoft Windows, OS X, Linux) – "''Firewatch'' is about solitude and space, a first-person journey through the massive wilderness of America's Shoshone National Forest. It's a space of such magnitude that it almost unavoidably conjures mysteries and conspiracies of corresponding size. But in this game, we are drawn back down to the essential and human."<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/feb/08/firewatch-review-first-person-simulation-adventure-game/ | title = Firewatch Review - A Small Game with a Big Story | first = Nathan | last = Ditum | date = February 8, 2016 | accessdate = May 13, 2017}}</ref> *''[[The Witness (2016 video game)|The Witness]]'' (2016, PlayStation 4, Microsoft Windows, OS X) – "''The Witness'' does something that you can't do with any other art form. This game has a clear message: 'Change your perspective', and unless you do so, you can not succeed. Every aspect (i.e. gameplay, design, puzzles) of ''The Witness'' is based upon this idea."<ref>{{cite web | url = https://medium.com/the-cube/the-witness-games-as-a-form-of-art-2a9e2ec57079 | title = The Witness: Games as a Form of Art | first = Emre | last = Saglik | date = April 20, 2016 | accessdate = May 13, 2017}}</ref> *''[[Inside (video game)|Inside]]'' (2016, Xbox One, Microsoft Windows) – Playdead's followup to ''Limbo'', ''Inside'' is a puzzle-platformer that follows an unnamed boy's trek across a surreal landscape while being chased by pursuers. It uses a wider array of cinematographic elements that, as described by Christopher Byrd of ''[[The Washington Post]]'', "It's a mood piece, a series of expertly framed environments that escalate in their strangeness."<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/comic-riffs/wp/2016/07/06/inside-review-a-gaming-masterpiece/ | title = ‘Inside’ review: A gaming masterpiece | first = Christopher | last = Byrd | date = 6 July 2016 | accessdate = 11 July 2016 | work = [[Washington Post]] }}</ref> *''[[The Last Guardian]]'' (2016, PlayStation 4) – The third [[Team Ico]] game, following ''Ico'' and ''Shadow of the Colossus'', designed around a realistic-acting giant bird-cat-like creature that the player must learn to tend and care for as to be able to entice the creature to help solve puzzles.<ref name="ew e3 2015"/> *''[[Virginia (video game)|Virginia]]'' (2016, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, PC, OS X) – A first-person mystery thriller adventure game using a strong cinematographic language in the style of David Lynch films.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/virginia/b/playstation4/archive/2016/09/22/game-informer-virginia-review.aspx|title=Virginia Review – An Elegant And Riveting Thriller|website=Game Informer|language=en|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref> *''[[The Town of Light]]'' (2016, PS4, Xbox One, Microsoft Windows) – A 3D adventure in first person view about madness and ancient psychiatric asylums horrors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2017/06/06/review-the-town-of-light/259506/|title=Review: The Town of Light {{!}} Hardcore Gamer|access-date=2017-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gaming/what-to-play/the-town-of-light-review/|title=The Town of Light is a gruelling but worthy exploration of a wretched era in mental therapy|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-08-17|language=en-GB}}</ref> * ''[[Hyper Light Drifter]]'' (2016, Xbox One, PS4, Microsoft Windows) – an action role-playing game developed by [[Heart Machine]]. The game was praised for its visual storytelling, hack and slash combat, emotional storyline and anime-inspired 8-bit visuals.<ref>http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-04-06-hyper-light-drifter-review</ref><ref>http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/hyper-light-drifter</ref><ref>http://www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/video-games/editorials/reviews/16981-Hyper-Light-Drifter-Review#&gid=gallery_6124&pid=1</ref> * ''[[Night in the Woods]]'' (2017, PS4, Xbox One, PC, OS X) – A single-player [[exploration game]] developed by Infinite Fall about an anthropomorphic cat named Mae, who dropped out of college and has returned to her slowly dying hometown to find that a lot has changed since she left. It is a game that has "a fantastic narrative with a beautiful art-style, theme and plenty of small touches occupying a wonderful world full of loving characters covering a sinister story underneath".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gamingtrend.com/reviews/when-the-world-grows-with-you-night-in-the-woods-review/|title=When the world grows without you, Night in the Woods Review|work=GAMING TREND|access-date=2017-04-25|language=en-US}}</ref> * ''[[What Remains of Edith Finch]]'' (2017, PS4, Xbox One, PC) – Indie studio [[Giant Sparrow]] conjures an adventure that blends exploration, reading, reality and fantasy into one innovative and beautiful experience.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/apr/26/what-remains-of-edith-finch-review-giant-sparrow|title=What Remains of Edith Finch review: magical ode to the joy of storytelling|last=Ramanan|first=Chella|date=2017-04-26|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-05-02|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> * ''[[Hollow Knight]]'' (2017, Nintendo Switch, Microsoft Windows, PS4) – A [[Metroidvania]]-style hack and slash platform game developed by Team Cherry about an insect warrior trying save a town from a terrible curse.<ref>http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/hollow-knight</ref><ref>http://www.pcgamer.com/hollow-knights-charming-art-sets-the-bar-for-hand-drawn-games/</ref><ref>https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2017/03/02/hollow-knight-review/</ref> * ''Last Day of June'' (2017, PS4, Microsoft Windows) – A 3D graphic adventure with a colorful cartoon aesthetics reminding of Tim Burton's films in stop motion. The game's story is about love and loss, life and death, and is like a puzzle.<ref name=":0" /> Soundtrack is composed by [[Steven Wilson]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://es.ign.com/last-day-of-june-ps4/122738/review/last-day-of-june-analisis-para-ps4-y-pc|title=Last Day of June. Análisis para PS4 y PC|date=2017-08-30|work=IGN España|access-date=2017-09-09|language=es-ES}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://it.ign.com/last-day-of-june-ps4/130144/review/last-day-of-june-la-recensione|title=Last Day of June - La recensione|date=2017-08-29|work=IGN Italia|access-date=2017-09-09|language=it-IT}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hobbyconsolas.com/reviews/analisis-last-day-june-cuento-amor-perdida-ps4-pc-162106|title=Análisis de Last Day of June, un cuento de amor y pérdida para PS4 y PC|work=HobbyConsolas|access-date=2017-09-09|language=es}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2017-08-31-the-last-day-of-june-review|title=Last Day of June review|last=Hood|first=Vic|date=2017-08-31|website=Eurogamer|language=en-UK|access-date=2017-09-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/last-day-of-june-review/1900-6416746/|title=Last Day Of June Review|last=Newhouse|first=Alex|date=2017-08-29|website=GameSpot|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-09}}</ref> *''[[Gorogoa]]'' (2017, PS4, Xbox One, PC, Nintendo Switch, iOS) – A puzzle game presented with four images in a grid in which the player arrange, combine, and explore each image to find a connection between them in order to advance the story. The creator who developed ''Gorogoa'', Jason Roberts, draw by hand all the scenes;<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.pcgamer.com/2012/10/11/gorogoa-indie-surreal-puzzler/ |title= Gorogoa is a completely hand-drawn puzzler of Magritte-esque surrealism |date= 11 October 2012 |accessdate=2018-06-10|first= Omri |last= Petitte |work= PC Gamer}}</ref> he cites [[David Roberts (illustrator)|David Roberts]], [[Gustave Doré]], [[Christopher Manson]], and [[Chris Ware]] as influences to his art style.<ref name="PCG">{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/previews/gorogoa-first-look-a-charming-and-beautiful-illustrative-puzzle-game/|title=Gorogoa first look: a charming and beautiful illustrative puzzle game|last=Warr|first=Philippa|date=23 December 2013|accessdate=2 January 2014|work=[[PC Gamer]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/211040/Road_to_the_IGF_Jason_Roberts_Gorogoa/|title=Road to the IGF: Jason Roberts' Gorogoa|last=Graft|first=Kris|date=18 February 2014|accessdate=2018-06-10|work=[[Gamasutra]]}}</ref> *''The Invisible Hours'' (2017, PS4, Xbox One, PC) – ''The Invisible Hours'' is an [[Agatha Christie]]-style murder mystery, a classic whodunit similar to ''[[And Then There Were None]]''; it is also heavily inspired by [[Christopher Nolan]]'s film [[The Prestige (film)|''The Prestige'']]. Six people with an obscure past (among them inventor [[Thomas Edison]]) are invited by scientist [[Nikola Tesla]] to his mansion on an uninhabited and isolated little island. Tesla is murdered. It was presented at NEXT during the [[Cannes Film Festival]] 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gamecritics.com/daniel-weissenberger/the-invisible-hours-review/|title=The Invisible Hours Review|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pushsquare.com/reviews/ps4/the_invisible_hours|title=The Invisible Hours Review|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/310750/Game_Design_Deep_Dive_Creating_the_spherical_narrative_in_The_Invisible_Hours.php|title=Game Design Deep Dive: Creating the 'spherical narrative' in The Invisible Hours|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tequilaworks.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/The_Invisible_Hours_Cannes_Press_Release_Final.pdf|title=NEXT|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://vgartsite.wordpress.com/2018/05/28/the-invisible-hours/|title=The Invisible Hours|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> *''[[11-11: Memories Retold]]'' (2018, PS4, XBO, Win) - Story-driven 3D adventure and interactive drama set during World War I. it is an antithesis to the common shooters. It ambitions to echo the centenary of '''[[World War I]]''' so that the younger generations never forget. Universally acclaimed for its [[Vincent van Gogh|Van Gogh]]-like aesthetics opening new expressive possibilities and introducing technical innovations with great impact for the future of gaming.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/gaming/11-memories-retold-review-ww1-world-war-ps4-xbox-gameplay-aardman-a8616936.html|title=11-11: Memories Retold review: A splash of humanity to something as inhumane as war|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/11/08/11-11-memories-retold-review-beauty-garlanded-in-hell-8116418/|title=Game review: 11-11 Memories Retold is a moving First World War tribute|date=2018-11-08|work=Metro|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vgartsite.wordpress.com/2018/11/17/11-11-memories-retold-review/|title=11-11: Memories Retold – Review|date=2018-11-17|work=Video Games Art|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.trustedreviews.com/reviews/11-11-memories-retold|title=11-11 Memories Retold Review {{!}} Trusted Reviews|work=Trusted Reviews|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-US}}</ref> *''[[Red Dead Redemption 2]]'' (2018, PS4, XBO) - A large open world game set in the [[American frontier]], the title is noted for creating background settings, characters, wildlife, and other events to make the game immersive, while emphasizing the impact that the choices a player makes on how the player later interacts with these elements.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/23/opinion/sunday/red-dead-redemption-2-fallout-76-video-games.html | title = Red Dead Redemption 2 Is True Art | first = Peter | last = Suderman | date = November 23, 2018 | accessdate = November 24, 2018 | work = [[The New York Times]] }}</ref>

"'''Little Expressionless Animals'''" is a 1988 short story by [[David Foster Wallace]]. It was first published in ''[[The Paris Review]]'', and reprinted in his short story collection ''[[Girl with Curious Hair]]''. The ''[[Village Voice]]'' described it as "riveting".<ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/2000-08-22/news/trivial-necessities/ ''Trivial Necessities: How to Win Friends and Influence People''], Hillary Chute, [[Village Voice]], August 22 2000</ref> The main narrative of the story is told in a cut-up style, with events taking place in a nonlinear fashion to increase dramatic tension.
==Plot== Julie Smith is a contestant on ''[[Jeopardy!]]'', an American television game show, in the 1980s. After her fourth win, the show's producers decide that she is popular enough that they will not limit her to five appearances (as was the practice at the time). As a result, Julie wins every ''Jeopardy!'' game for three years, and uses her winnings to pay for the care of her [[autistic]] brother.
As Julie consistently wins every ''Jeopardy!'' match, studio executive [[Merv Griffin]] decides to increase the tension within the show by secretly convincing Julie's brother to compete against her, and rigs the game in his favor by selecting only questions that relate to animals — the only category with which Julie struggles.

The '''Lynn Painter-Stainers Prize''' is an annual art award, intended to encourage creative representational painting and draughtsmanship. It gives out prizes totalling £25,000.<ref name="AN ruth stage">{{cite news|author= |url=http://new.a-n.co.uk/news/single/lynn-painter-stainers-prize-2013-winners-announced |work=a-n.co.uk |title=Lynn Painter-Stainers Prize 2013 winners announced |date=19 February 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> The prize originated in [[London]] in 2005,<ref name="BBC 2012 fan">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17528781 |work=BBC News |title=Lynn Painter-Stainers Prize won by electric fan work |publisher= |date=28 March 2012 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> with a collaboration between the [[Worshipful Company of Painter-Stainers]] and the Lynn Foundation. The final exhibition has been held at the [[Mall Galleries]], London, since 2012.<ref name="the prize">{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.lynnpainterstainersprize.org.uk/the-prize/ |title=The Prize |publisher=Lynnpainterstainersprize.org.uk |date= |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref>
==Winners== ''[[The Independent]]'' reviewed the 2009 exhibition favourably, saying "The means are relatively traditional – oil on board, oil on canvas, acrylic on canvas, etc. The range is, at first glance, familiar: landscape, ruminative portraiture, still life... What we look for in any show such as this one is the way in which the painter has engaged with his or her subject, the particular angle of attack... This does not necessarily mean being wildly experimental so that the world as we know it disappears altogether. There is none of that here. And yet abstraction does play a part, and often quite a subtle one."<ref name="Indy 2009">{{cite news|author=[[Michael Glover (author)|Michael Glover]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/reviews/lynn-painterstainers-prize-exhibition-painters-hall-london-1821719.html |work=The Independent |title=Lynn Painter-Stainers Prize Exhibition, Painters' Hall, London |publisher= |date=17 November 2009 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref>
Selector Steve Pill, shared his thoughts on the selection of the exhibition: "I was keen to try and view each work from the perspective of a wider audience. The two stated aims of the Lynn Painter-Stainers Prize are to encourage creative representational painting and promote the skill of draughtsmanship, so I often asked myself: would we be fulfilling that promise by including this work? Would a visitor expecting these qualities be truly satisfied by every painting we chose? I hope you’ll agree that we have stayed true to those principles and selected a collection of work that really celebrates the vitality, diversity and skill of contemporary representational painting in the UK today."
The 2012 prize was won by Anthony Williams for a [[still life]] painting of an [[electric fan]]. 98 paintings were selected for the final exhibition.<ref name="BBC 2012 fan" />
In 2013 the prize winner was artist [[Ruth Stage]], for her [[tempera]] painting ''The Isabella Plantation''. Stage received £15,000 and a gold medal.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-21499549 |work=BBC News |title=Egg artist wins £15,000 art prize |publisher= |date=18 February 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> There were five judges; artist [[Nina Murdoch (artist)|Nina Murdoch]], former winner [[Antony Williams (artist)|Antony Williams]], art critic Andrew Lambirth and Tate fellow Andrew Wilton who picked the winners from 72 finalists.<ref name="Indy lynn painter">{{cite news|author=Daisy Wyatt |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/ruth-stage-wins-lynn-painterstainers-prize-for-figurative-art-8500739.html |work=[[The Independent]] |title=Ruth Stage wins Lynn Painter-Stainers prize for figurative art |publisher= |date=19 February 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> A young artist prize was also awarded (worth £2,500) and there were five runners-up spots.<ref name="Indy lynn painter" />
The 2014 prize was won by Edinburgh-based artist [[Catharine Davison]] for her 'mesmerising' en plain air painting [[Craggs at Dawn (Calton Hill)]]. During a private award ceremony, 17 March 2014, Davidson was presented with the £15,000 prize in addition to an engraved gold medal. The Young Artist Award of £2,500 was awarded to University of Brighton student, Charlie Schaffer, for his work, Antonio. Five runner-up prizes of £1,500 each were awarded to; Peter Archer for Causeway; Wylie Craig for MD (Pierced); Anabel Cullen for Untitled (Adrian Gillian); Benjamin Hope for Self portrait in leftover paint; and David Tebbs for Catwalk No.1. The 2014 exhibition comprised 85 works by 78 artists selected by a prestigious panel of judges; Peter Clossick, Artist; Ken Howard OBE RA NEAC, Artist; Paul Newland, Artist; Steve Pill, Editor Artists and Illustrators magazine; and Andrew Wilton, Visiting Research Fellow at Tate Britain. 2014.
===First Prize winners=== <ref>[http://www.lynnpainterstainersprize.org.uk/exhibition/ "Lynn Painter-Stainers Prize"]</ref> * 2005 Michael Bilton for ''Early Morning Mist'' * 2006 [[John Lessor]] for ''Vincent, Timothy and Samuel'' * 2007 [[Benjamin Sullivan (artist)|Benjamin Sullivan]] for ''New Life'' * 2008 [[Melissa Scott-Miller]] for ''Islington Kids'' * 2009 [[Toby Wiggins]] for ''Suspended Animation'' * 2010 [[Rachel Levitas]] for ''Urban Fox III''<ref name="BBC 2012 fan" /> * 2011 ''No award?'' * 2012 Anthony Williams for ''Still Life with Electric Fan'' * 2013 [[Ruth Stage]] for ''The Isabella Plantation'' * 2014 [[Catharine Davidson]] for ''The Craggs at Dawn (from Calton Hill)''<ref>"[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-26610572 In Pictures: Lynn Painter-Stainers Prize 2014]". [[BBC News]], 17 March 2014. Accessed 22 April 2017</ref>

[[File:trapelacucha drawing.svg|thumb|150px|Drawing of a trapelacucha, a silver finery piece.|right]] '''Mapuche silverwork''' is one of the best known aspects of [[Mapuche]] material culture.<ref name=Painecura15>Painecura 2011, p. 15.</ref> The adornments have been subject to changes in fashion but some designs have resisted change.
==History== In the later half of the 18th century, Mapuche [[silversmith]]s began to produce large amounts of silver finery.<ref name=Aldunate>{{cite journal |last=Aldunate |first=Carlos |last2= |first2= |year=1984 |title=Reflexiones acerca de la platería mapuche |url=http://repositoriodigital.uct.cl:8080/xmlui/bitstream/handle/123456789/329/CUHSO_0716-1557_03_1984_1_art1.pdf?sequence=1 |journal=Cultura-Hombre-Sociedad |publisher= |volume=1 |issue= |pages= |doi= |accessdate=13 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203065926/http://repositoriodigital.uct.cl:8080/xmlui/bitstream/handle/123456789/329/CUHSO_0716-1557_03_1984_1_art1.pdf?sequence=1 |archivedate=3 December 2013 |df= }}</ref> The surge of silversmithing activity may be related to the [[Parliament of Quillín (1641)|1641 parliament of Quillín]] and the [[1726 parliament of Negrete]] that decreased hostilities between Spaniards and Mapuches and allowed trade to increase between [[colonial Chile]] and the free Mapuches.<ref name=Aldunate/><ref name=Painecura25-26/> In this context of increasing trade, Mapuches began in the late 18th century to accept payments in [[silver coin]]s for their products; usually cattle or horses.<ref name=Aldunate/> These coins and silver coins obtained in political negotiations served as raw material for Mapuche metalsmiths ([[Mapudungun]]: ''rüxafe'').<ref name=Aldunate/><ref name=Painecura25-26/><ref name=Kangiser/> Old Mapuche silver [[pendant]]s often included unmelted silver coins, something that has helped modern researchers to date the objects.<ref name=Kangiser>{{cite journal |last=Kangiser Gómez |first=María Fernanda |last2= |first2= |year=2002 |title=Conservación en platería mapuche: Museo Fonck, Viña del Mar |url=http://www.museodevalparaiso.cl/dinamicas/DocAdjunto_27.pdf |journal=Conserva |publisher= |volume=6 |issue= |pages= |doi= |accessdate=13 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202234953/http://www.museodevalparaiso.cl/dinamicas/DocAdjunto_27.pdf |archivedate=2 December 2013 |df= }}</ref> The bulk of the Spanish silver coins originated from mining in [[Potosí]] in [[Upper Peru]].<ref name=Painecura25-26>Painecura 2011, pp. 25-26.</ref>
The great diversity in silver finery designs is indebted to the fact that designs were done to be identified with different ''reynma'' (families), ''lof mapu'' (lands) as well as specific [[lonko]]s and [[machi (shaman)|machi]]s.<ref name=Painecura27-28>Painecura 2011, pp. 27-28.</ref> Mapuche silver finery was also subject to changes in [[fashion]] albeit designs associated with philosophical and spiritual concepts have not undergone major changes.<ref name=Painecura27-28/>
In late 18th century and early 19th century, Mapuche silversmithing activity and artistic diversity reached it climax.<ref name=Painecura30>Painecura 2011, p. 30.</ref> All important Mapuche chiefs of the 19th century are supposed to have had at least one silversmith.<ref name=Aldunate/> The [[Occupation of Araucanía|1869 war between Chile and independent Mapuches]] provoked a famine among Mapuches in the winter of 1869, with the situation being worsened by a [[smallpox]] epidemic.<ref name=Bengoa224>Bengoa 2000, p. 224.</ref> This situation led some Mapuches to sell their silver adornments in the towns of [[La Frontera, Chile|La Frontera]] to obtain food.<ref name=Bengoa224/>
As of 1984, Mapuche scholar Carlos Aldunate noted that there were no silversmiths alive among contemporary Mapuches.<ref name=Aldunate/>
==Appearance== Although these adornments showed some variation in form, the principal one appears to be a set of three separate columns of flattened silver links joined to each other by square alternating links. At the top of the set of columns, and holding them together, is a flat two-headed bird figure and at the base is a flat semicircle or trapezoid that usually has a series of small disks dangling from its base. The wearer would place the object hanging from his/ her neck and down the chest.
